reviewText: Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Directors Cut is a breath of fresh air, especially after the disappointing sequel to one of my favourite games of all time, Deus Ex. Invisible War was a mess. BUT, Human Revolution rejuvenated the franchise after returning to the core roots and pillars of gameplay which were founded in the original. Stealth, action, meaningful choice and consequence events, and of course many other role playing elements. Adam Jensen, ex-SWAT and military, is an awesome protagonist, and is easily one of the franchises best characters, just as JC Denton was in the first game. Augmentations are back, and are as awesome as ever. These give Adam a slick feel, especially as time progresses, and allows endless possibilities with character development. Augmentations give the player new avenues into approaching objectives which allows the game to feel more open ended and replayable.BE WARNED, not all augmentations can be purchased in one playthrough so choose wisely depending on your playstyle.5th time playing it myself (1st time on PC), and I was still discovering new and rewarding approaches to tackle my objectives. The dialogue system, which is very similar to Mass Effect, works extremely well in giving the player more choice and is intricately designed, much like the new hacking system. As far as the story goes, it absolutely works with the themes of the game. Conspiracies, secret organisations and of course...the Illuminati. And not to mention, the writing in the game is impeccable. One of the best scripts I've seen in a video game.\n\nThe Directors Cut" tag has added quite a few benefits over the original
date: the most noticeable being the New Game+ mode which was widely requested by fans for a long time. It's here and it absolutely works. Being able to continue on from where the game ended and keeping all augmentations just makes the game more enjoyable and also a little bit easier
recommended: allowing the "Give me Deus Ex" difficulty to be quite manageable

reviewText:
The good: I don't know what I can say about the amazing Deus Ex universe that hasn't already been said. Human Revolution is incredibly immersive; the enviroment is beautiful, the characters well rounded (even the side characters), and the story compelling (espeically if you take time to read the avaliable material and track down clues off the beaten path). The gameplay is fun, especially if you enjoy stealth games. The soundtrack is amazing; check out the cinematic trailer if you want a good example of this. If you're a stealth player, this game will really allow you to shine.

The bad: Human Revolution encourages you to take a stealth approach, which runs a little contrary to the prior Deus Ex games, in which multiple paths were equally rewarding. You get more in-game rewards for stealth and non-lethal approaches. I'd have liked to see a more balanced approach. Also under bad, the boss fights were developed by a different company, so they really don't fit the feel of the rest of the game.

Director's Cut specific notes: The Director's Cut attempted to fix the boss battles, and they are certainly much better than they were in prior versions; however, you still have to kill the bosses, which is jarring in the midst of a non-lethal run. Many people have experienced performance issues with the Director's Cut. Those with Nvidia graphics cards seem to experience more difficulty on the whole; however, a lot of it is down to your configuration. I'm running a Nvidia card in a laptop and I'm able to play the DC without any framerate or stuttering issues. However, your mileage may vary - something to be aware of.

General info: All of the DLCs available with the original Human Revolution have been integrated into the Director's Cut (except for the 10,000 credit bonus). The extra weapons are now available in-game as opposed to being dropped into your inventory from the beginning, and the Tong mission and Missing Link are both part of the story line.

Overall: This is my favorite game, to be honest, and I would strongly recommend it to absolutely anyone. The story is great, and if you care to spend any time seriously contemplating it, can raise some interesting questions about technology and humanity. If you haven't played the Deus Ex games, do yourself a favor and play them ASAP.

System Specs Used: Intel Core i7-3610QM, Nvidia GeForce GTX 670M / 3GB GDDR5, DDRIII 12GB RAM, Windows 7

reviewText:
I had a blast.

---

Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Director's Cut is the first and only game yet, that I played from this series. As the original game came out in 2000, it wasn't the type of game I liked to play back then. And the sequel from 2003 seemed to be a disappointment. So I skipped these games...

... and I got more than positively surprised, without knowing what I had to expect:

The gameplay with all his diversity is awesome. It's always your decision how you play (upseen from the boss fights). You can be a stone cold killer, a tactician, hacker or a sissy. That's also depending on the cool assorment of augmentations (skills") from which you can choose.

The atmosphere/graphic/audio is amazing. You get literally drawn into the world of cyberpunk. Only the textures and cutscenes could have a higher resolution for a game that was released in 2011.

One thing I didn't liked was "The Missing Link" DLC which got added to the last third of the story mode. It just doesnt't fit in. Upseen from that... if you want to check out everything while playing the game.. hacking stuff and reading (all) ebooks can be a little bit bugging. But just a bit.

I give it a 9/10"

reviewText:
Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a fascinating and exciting First Person RPG.  The game is set in a fully immersive new-age cyber-punk world.  This game is the third produced in the series but is actually the prequel to the first two games.  The game revolves around what makes your character human, you acquire biotech abilities in an accident and the story starts there.

Pros:
+This game has one of the best backstories and additional immersive written content.  I would equate it to playing Mass Effect at times with all the little journals and stories to read.
+ As you progress you have the ability to customize your biotech.  You can pick from a variety of upgrade trees and abilities both passive and active.
+Graphics are amazingly crisp and detailed.
+The gameplay is fluid and even though the game is set in the future, the physics are realistic.
+The game offers a variety of difficulties
+Maybe some of the best music I have heard in a game in quite sometime
+The quality of the sound effects is something to be heard as well.
+ You have the ability to play most missions stealthy or loud.

+/- The stealth system is nothing too unique and combat can be repetitive
+/- The game is set in an open world environment but sometimes you feel it’s a bit linear after all.

Cons:
- Lacking weapon variety.
- Ending is anti-climactic and lacking.

Verdict:
9

I look forward to seeing this series continue and develop.  If you want a challenge, a game set in the future and/ or a stealth based game this can be lots of fun.  If you want a straight up shooter this may not fully impress you.

Full Review based on PS3 Console Play, but equally as beautiful and executed on PC.

reviewText:
Short Review	Deus Ex is a very polished FPS with RPG elemtns, boasting a moderate amount of replayability depending on your interests. The Director's Cut edition offers an extra set of missions in the middle of the original story.

8/10

PROS
- Polished gameplay, very few bugs
- Visuals are nice
- Content-rich world
- Fun storyline and side-missions
- A wide range of useful and interesting character upgrades
- Reasonably good AI
- Well-designed environments and levels

CONS
- A somewhat limited amount of weapons and weapon upgrades
- Not quite a true open-world experience due to the storyline, which hurts the replayability a bit
- The director's cut story can be frustrating to play as you temporarily lose your character's weaponry and hard-earned upgrades.



Full Review	Deus Ex is a FPS with an RPG element where in you unlock and upgrade an array of built-in cyborg capabilities. You can even upgrade your weapons with modifications like laser sights, ammo capacity increases and explosive rounds just to name a few. This aspect stays somewhat true to the original.

Gameplay is smooth, but may feel a little clumsy at times when aiming with guns. Sometimes in the heat of a shootout it can feel a bit sluggish trying to gun down enemies whilst strafing around. So keep in mind this is not a shooter like Halo or CoD where you can move around very quickly dodging fire. You need to pick your positions carefully to ensure a clear shot and safe cover.

The way Deus Ex is meant to be played is taking cover behind objects in your environment, and either gunning down your enemies - or stealth. The stealth mechanics of the game are brilliant. Enemies are very aware of noise and are smart enough to check areas thoroughly if they suspect an intruder is there. If you accidentally alert enemies to your presence, you often have to back out of the whole area unnoticed if you want to remain hidden.

Not only is stealth fun, but the game is highly rewarding of stealth tactics. Enemies are typically easier to kill if you can sneak up on them, you can slip through areas quickly if you plan your movement correctly, and you get bonus experience points for stealth kills and mission objectives. This allows for faster character levelling.

If you prefer to empty your guns in each room, that's also very fun, but the enemies don't make it easy. Very rarely can you pull a rambo in this game and get away with it. Enemies shoot accurately and will quickly make easy work of you if you are not adequately positioned or equipped with sufficient firepower.

The visuals are great and most elements in the game are nicely detailed. The environments are awesomely put together. The atmospheric places of America, China and the fictional Panchea create an immersive experience which feels exciting, disturbing, suspenseful and curious all at the same time. In addition to the graphical detail, the areas have many avenues for exploring which can reward you with hidden items, such as powerful weapons and bonus upgrades. Many areas are only accessible after acquiring certain upgrades to your character (e.g. jumping higher and withstandning electrical damage) which adds another entertaining level of complexity to the game.

It is led by an in-depth storyline with many twists and turns. The main storyline involves hunting down several super-powered soldiers, using similar technology to yourself, in an attempt to find the protagonist's girlfriend (ex... sorta... you'll see) as well as following the suspicious orders of his boss. There are plenty of side-missions which are a good source for extra content and bonus experience and cash.

Overall, Deus Ex: HR - DC is worth the current price of $20 as it does provide some good replayability. You can play through the game using different styles and upgrades and it provides a different experience with each way. If it goes on sale, it is definitely worth picking up to play through at least once.

8/10

reviewText: Deus Ex: Human Revolution is an engrossing and spectacular game. Comparatively to the original, the story flows better and to a degree gameplay seem slightly easier. It's imperfect sure, but leaves me enthralled in both the world and story. reviewText:
After playing through it a second time I realized this one does admittedly get a bit of a free pass because of the disaster that was Invisible War. That having been said, I feel as though there was heart, polish and lots of effort put into this project, so I can overlook that and still say it's good and worth a play. Deus Ex levels of great? No. Still good and worth experiencing? Absolutely.

As for the Missing Link, it is standard fare as far as DLC go. Very short, it challenges you by limiting your resources and has (mostly) good rewards. Oh, and ends on a very ambiguous and vague note.

Shame the endings are all still terrible. Oh well, can't win them all.

reviewText:
Deus Ex Human Revolution is a very fun FPS/RPG game with, just like the first game in the series, many varieties to approach the situations, either stealthy or run & gun with many weapons & gadgets.

The gameplay is where it shines but also plummets what it comes to complexity.

Dumbed down gameplay mechanics
1. Augmentations

To unlock & upgrade your augmentations, you need Praxis points.
Unlocking costs 2 Praxis points & upgrading 1 for each upgrade.
That already is a red flag.

You can get some good augmentations quite early, especially if you are stealthy & go for pacifist run since you gain more XP.

There are four ways to get Praxis points:
- By acquiring required XP points
- Buying them in LIMB clinic (5000 credits each (you get quite a lot of credits really fast))
- Completing some side-quests
- Exploring the world

Example: Cloaking requires four Praxis points to be unlocked & fully upgraded & if you have a lot of candy bars aka CyberBoost ProEnergy Bars, you are already op pretty much plus if you are conservative, you use cloak only between covers.

In original Deus Ex, skills & augs were two separate things & with augs, you couldn't get powerful ones early. You had to explore for them, find MedBots to install them, plus find the aug upgrade canisters by, again, exploring.

As for skills, every time you upgraded one of the skills, the next upgrade cost even more points.

So there is that. It clearly shows simplified rpg elements with that comparison.

2. Takedowns

Melee weapons don't exist. What you do is you kill or knock out a person
with a single button press (or holding it to kill). While in quite cool animation, the time stops, so you are safe during that time.

In the original Deus Ex, you had a baton & other lethal melee weapons.
You actually had to aim at the back of the enemy & knock him out or kill him, while being vulnerable & prone to being detected.

3. Doors being locked only by a keypad

Wish there could be a better variety of doors or safes being locked with.
Like locks or something.

4. Too many air vents

It took me out of the immersion to see so many air vents in the game.
Sure, you don't have to use them but it doesn't change the game being dumbed down like crazy.

You'll be like Oh
recommended:
I can safely sneak past the guards."

These dumbed down gameplay mechanics can be a matter of an opinion.
So
hoursPlayed:
it's either plus or minus for some people.

Boss battles
Everybody have already said their thoughts on bosses in this game.
For me
voteText: first boss was indeed terrible work but the other two weren't that bad
helpfulPercent: though they were easy.\n\nThing is
votesHelpful: you are forced to kill them while doing the pacifist approach.\nIt's not about carrying a gun with you against them
votesTotal: since the arenas have more than enough weapons & ammunition to kill them.\n\nBut the fact that
votesFunny:
it's Deus Ex. You ought to have choices to either fight them
or let them live to help you or not.

What does Director's cut change? Well
commentsCount: the arena you fight them

column17: so it ain't only with weapons.\n\nNot great but it is something. I heard Mankind Divided will change this by giving you a choice to fight them
column18: or talked to them & convince them not to fight you & what not.\nHopefully

so they aren't something you should care about.

Vending machine endings
This is a spoiler-free issue I'd like to point out.

Like the original Deus Ex & unlike Invisible War
column22:
your consequences during the game don't affect the endings at all.
It's literally a select-the-ending button & nothing else.

I heard it's because of the budget & time restraint
column23:
so hopefully they will bring a change to Mankind Divided.

People may crap on Invisible War but at least that game had something improved over its predecessor & successor.

Other flaws
- There are two kinds of people. Those who prefer stealth & others

who prefer run & gun.
The issue is that run & gun rewards you less than stealthy approach.
This can be quite a turn off for action players as they would see that there is no point of playing
it that way if they don't get rewarded as equally as the other play-style.

then give me a choice to continue after the game is loaded.

This goes to every game that does this.

Conclusion

reviewText: One of the best shooter-RPG hybrid I ever tried. I don't like shooters, but I love RPG, and I love cyberpunk genre. Mature, meaningful, interesting story bought me completely. I strongly recommend it.

Pros:
-Good graphics for its time
-Cutscenes are usually enjoyable
-Gameplay is good/stealth is easy to learn and there is actually an excuse for regenerating health
-Settings is captured very well

Cons:
-The Boss fights; Although the boss fights featured in DXHR: Directors Cut are much better than in the original game they still need a lot of work.

I enjoyed this game a lot and it is also one of my favorite games ever
So in conclusion I would recommend buying it.
This is one of my favorite games of all time! Havent played it on the computer yet but on console ive beaten it over 10 times.
Killstreak daaaaaaaaym

I played through the entire game on the hardest difficulty completely pascifist. Unfortunately, some prick I knocked unconscious decided to fall into some electrified water.... No acheivement for me.\nOtherwise.... why haven't you bought this game already?

It's one of those very few games that are mixing together different gameplay elements in the right way.
Deus Ex is a Stealth-RPG-FPS-Action lore heavy game. It is really standing out in every aspect and everything is executed in the right way.
The story is great, varied, with many twists. The characters are memorable, layered, the conversations feel very natural, the writing is awesome.
There are many moral choices and all lead to different conclusions. There are different endings and overall the lore of the game is somewhat ironically feels like it's pointing the finger to our real world. You will see some of teh best looking endings in gaming history.
The gameplay is polished, the rpg elements are simple to understand and well implemented.
Yous simply have everything here... Queasts, sidequests, different collectibles, reading materials. You can solve missions in many ways, somewhat reminding you of games like the Hitman series just in a Cyberpunk enviroment. Yep you can be like Hulk, Rambo, Leon the professional, or Sam Fisher to tackle your missions, using your enviroment in many different ways.
I strongly recomend this game to any gamer regardless of what type of game you like to play, it feels like there si something and everything for anyone here.
I love it! Being Sneaky dude I enjoyed this game immensely! Sooooo much atmosphere in the game it almost oozed out of the screen and speakers. Get this game!
Translated the Deus Ex formula in to modern times [almost] perfectly.

An amazing game with great combat and stealth systems, personalised abilities and awesome storyline.

Issue are the small maps and need to re-visit areas, the lost of all upgrades during one mission set which is very annoying, seeing the same NPC faces every two seconds.

Go a head and pick this game up its awesome if your a fan of metal gear or any other stealth games. also involves some moral checks ,,,,, I always start non- lethal and switch cause its more fun to head shot guards with lethal and know they aint getting up

rate 9/10

reviewText: This is an AMAZING game. If you like stealth games then Deux Ex HR is the best one out there.

a very fun game, wether you like RPG's, stealth, action or first person shooters, this is a game that really ticks all the boxes.
the combat is great, the leveling system is awesome and the story is just amazing, several plot twist will bend your mind back to front playing this game.the objectice is neve confusing like some games can, if you get stuck you just check the map and your fine. stealth is hard but rewarding a nd if playing on hard, its quite critical you master it.

the only problem i had with this game is that some of the powers/upgrades can sometimes be very over powered, for instance, the is a small bit in a game where you need to cross a big room and get to the elevator and 50 guards come in toward you. jensen has the ability to turn invisible (once you buy the ability) and all i did was turn invisible and run past them. it feels like some of the hardest bits of the game wernt as chalanging as i would have like the to be.

over all a perfect game for everyone     9.5/10  MUST BUY

This game is truly fantastic. Many have conflicting views on it's quality, but I believe truly that, having played the original game, its faults can be treated as homages to DX1, for instance, the poor sight range of npc AI. The overall art style is fantastic, and one I am still reeling at years after it's creation. I solidly believe that this game is a must-play for any who are a fan of RPGs or Sci-Fi action games.

I had a lot of fun with this game. I had a few technical issues playing it on my system, but nothing I couldn't get around. The levels were interesting and there is certainly some significant replay value to it since you can play the character in so many different ways.

Play full stealth or go in guns blazing or a combination and  it was a blast. The game allows you to play through without having to kill anyone (except boss battles), it's all up to your gaming style and personality.

A must have IMHO. :)

One of the best games ever made and also one of my personal favourites. A huge amount of passion went into the making of it and it really shows.

I've played through this version twice on PC, plus three times when the original was released on consoles, and I have to say that after 5+ playthroughs of the game the director's cut dramatically improves the experience and for me it is now the only way to play it.

The story is truly fantastic and caters for the player's style and choices made throughout the game.  The game's graphics and gameplay is also wonderful, albeit have a slightly dated feel to them due to the age of the game's engine (created 2007-2011), but in fairness these limitations are explained by the developers in the included commentary; either way, this does not ruin the game whatsoever and I thoroughly recommend it.
10/10\n\nOne of the best games I have ever played. I highly recommend this to anyone who likes FPS, deep stories, and cyber-punk / futuristic settings.

I didn't need another reason for a second playthrough, but since they've added new avenues (alt ways of beating bosses) and a few other tweaks, well, I'm all for that.  The most interesting thing is the staff commentary throughtout the game.  I found it very intersting and non-intrusive.
great game. 11/10.
Even though I just got this game, I played it long ago ...It's still my favourite game of all time!! A must get for 3rd person shooter

OK so I'm trying to do my first playthrough complete stealth and non lethal so my inventory is full of low damage weapons like a tranq gun and silenced pistol. So when I got to the first boss i was totally unprepared. I was trying to do a hit and run tactic when I stumbled on a couple of turrets... I went into the control room nect door hacked into the security hub and turned them on to attack enemies. So i went outside picked one up and held it in front of me like a minigun and COMPLETELY overkilled the first boss!!!

The stealth system is also really good featuring noise as a factor and using cover to try and hide yourself can make it very interesting. Combining with the fact that there are multiple ways to get to your objective it has a lot of replay ability.

Its story is also very good, well written and should keep u intruigued.

10/10 augumented bunnies
Much like Adam I never asked for this, THIS GAME.

Great follow up game after the first one, I personally loved the story line and the choices.

However the game sort of pushes you to play in sliently and hackings can get a bit boring at some point. Still I would reccommend it.
Great Game so far... stealth system is amazing and the main highlight. Only major issue was Director cut scenes may spoiler parts of the game storyline, wish it was just a DLC add-on.
About a 1 hour in game,started thinking of ManBearPig,and had a overlapse
This... Get it... Just get it.

One of the best FPS games I've ever played, together with the original title (which is a sequel to the DX:HR's storyline, and that I highly recommend as well). Its plot is deep and intriguing, it will put you in front of many moral choices and you will have to face the consequences of those choices. You can tailor your characters to your preference -- either stealthy, tough and heavily armed or a mix of both. You can even finish the game without hurting a single person, if you exclude the bosses. If you like science fiction (and cyborgs in particular) and spy/action stories, this is the game for you.\n\n9/10
I loved the original version of this game, and the directors cut improves the game so much. Possibly my favorite RPG ever made
Awesome story. It starts slow and picks up by orders of magnitude along the way. A solid 40-60 hours of gameplay. The hardest difficulty setting was very playable.

Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a great single player game that really makes you feel for your choices (untill the ending) Human Revolution has a wide vareity of gameplay options for any play style, loud and proud? sure. Sneaky and lethal? sure. knock everybody in the world out wiht tranq darts and a tazer? more power to you. while the gameplay can be little clunky and the interface can be a tad bit buggy from time to time.  While the story is great, the ending does have a bit of a lack luster response, not making note of any of your acheivemnets, which is out of place from the rest of the game, for example when a plane crashes during the middle of the game it is very hard (yet possible) to save the pilot. If the pilot is saved then later that game they will make an apearance and change the plot of the game. The game follows through with a great story and gameplay accented with great AI and Unique mechanics, with a total of 26.8 hour campain for a partial stealth run. This is a product worthy of recogniton.
Had one or two false starts. The gamelplay takes a bit of getting acustomed to, but overall the gameplay and story delivered.

Possibly better than the original Deus Ex! Only thing they could have improved is the graphics engine. I was unhappy with the boss battles in the original Human Revolution, but this Director's Cut fixes that completely.

One of the best games of the seventh generation, period. Actually the game provides many ways of approaching it's challenges, in my opinion if you want the full experience go for stealth, most of the perks acquired by the lv. up system will give you a boost regarding the stealth approach. Also this is one of those games that playing in the highest difficulty is actually fun rather than frustrating (again, with a stealth approach), it is all about patience and studying your enemies patterns. Now the story while based on science fiction is not that far off on what may occur in the future, it raises many philosophical dilemmas and shows the varios sides and opinions through different characters. I recommend this game to those that are fans of MGS or most stealh based games (that are well made), and to those who like to choose their own path in a deep and complex storyline.

I thought this was a great game to play since the original version was fun and addicting. I am not good at scores but this game to me was 9.5/10 because story was great, made me feel like I was in the game. With 2 upgrading systems in the game 1 for your character an 2 for your gun(s) which was very useful and hard to pick what I want. I reccomend this game to any Deus Ex fans who like the games
Althrough not as great as the original Deus Ex, Human Revolution is still amazing on it's own right. Full of atmosphere and an impressive story line that will sure to hook you in.
One of the most fun games I've had the joy of playing. It runs well on my PC and the gameplay is wondeful. A very good RPG.

A rock solid game on many levels. It is one of the best stealth games that I have come across in the last few years. Yet, it's not just a stealth game. It provides several playstyles in which you can utilize during the game. The replayability factor simply rises because of it, as you naturally are tempted into playthroughs targetted to specific goals and playstyles.

The graphics are solid, yet don't tax mid-range systems. Even some low end systems should be able to run with this title and still look decent. It's very easy on the eyes and the gpu at the same time. The story line is a cut above for it's genre, in my opinion. It has depth, color, imagination, and well-thought out twists and turns. When it's time to decide your stance in the world, you really feel like you're a part of this world. My advice is to not rush this game; don't view it as stages to be completed. Go everywhere, do everything... explore and take your time at each stage of the game... get lost in the character you're playing instead of the goal you're trying to achieve.

This game doesn't fall short many places, but that's not saying it's perfect. There's room for expansion and improvement. I, for one, am really looking forward to any news of a sequel worthy of to succeed this game and see where they go with this amazing creation. I say one that is worthy of this game, because this game is quite literally the best entry into this franchise and the other titles that bear it's Dues Ex mark can't even stand in the same arena as this entry in my opinion.

All in all, I give this game a 9/10 overall and highly recommend this game to anyone!
Elias Toufexis' voice will never cease to put a smile on my face :) Awesome game with suprisingly good graphics and a great storyline.
Awesome. Even better than I remember. The missing link DLC is a nice change of pace. Highly recommended.
Great game! Would play again after I am done.
Deus Ex: Human Revolution is my all time favorite game I love it, I highly recommend it.

It is quite linear concerning missions, but apart from this I liked the music and the different possible ways for tackling a mission and upgrading. The immersion is quite good and I have enjoyed it very much.
One of the Best!

As a fan of the original Deus Ex game, this game really does live up to what the original game stood for and does a lot more.  The story is awesome, not as conspiracy theorist as the original, but still an awesome story.  The gameplay is great as well, the stealth sections can seem a bit forced, making you use cover to stealth" around by hugging the walls

Never played any other deus ex but I am glad I started with this one. It is one of the best games I have ever played. It truly makes me want to play differently. Stealth, kill, pacifist, hacker, tank, CoD style. It has it all. It makes you think tactically to solve a problem.

Unlike Skyrim, where you start an archer, stay an archer. It's hard to experiment (in my opinion) unlike this game where everything just works in it own beautiful ways.

Hidden stashes, secret paths only available to certain skills. Everything just drags you in and makes you want to play more. You want to do the side quest. They are like mini-main quests. Very well made!

10/10
I never asked for this director's cut.

I love this game.  I completed the standard version 5 times.  So I bought the Directors Cut.  It has the 'Missing Link' DLC built into the storyline which makes sense, and adds a couple of hours extra gameplay, plus slightly revised boss battles.  I heartily recommend this game.

The original release was one of the best games of 2011, hands down. It has a deep, rich storyline and setting that fans of cyberpunk--from Blade Runner to Ghost in the Shell--will greatly appreciate. The gameplay is smooth and challenging, and players of games such as Metal Gear Solid, Mass Effect, Thief, and the original Deus Ex will find themselves right at home with this fantastic title.

With the Director's Cut, a few changes and additions have been made. The most notable of these are the inclusion of the DLC missions into the main campaign--the Missing Link is no longer a separate game--the improved boss fights, and the developer commentary. There were other minor changes, but many players may not notice these. The inclusion of the Missing Link chapter helps round out the storyline, as well as give the player the opportunity to redo his or her skill points, which was something missing from the original 2011 release.

The improved boss fights were appreciated, though the additional avenues of defeating the bosses will still take some quick thinking, or trial and error, to truly take advantage. For fans that want a more balanced approach to the game, where any style of play is rewarded, this is the edition to purchase.

Developer commentary in this version of the game is an interesting and valuable addition. It can be toggled on or off at the player's convenience, and many of the nodes offer intriguing insight into the minds of the game's creators. The only minor irritations with the commentary involve the nodes themselves. They are not always apparent in the game world, and once a node is playing it cannot be stopped without going into the main menu options and toggling the commentary off. Still, in spite of that minor oversight, the commentary is exciting to listen to and veteran players will appreciate it.

I highly recommend that new and old fans of Deus Ex: Human Revolution grab a copy of the Director's Cut.

For fans of the original title from 2000, this game is everything you could want and more. Without spoilers, the storyline was engrossing, weaving all the characters together into a network of conspiracy and intrigue. The time I needed to play through the game first-time was about 50 hours, so you're getting your $$'s worth in gaming content. The characters you encounter are memorable and unique in their own ways. (The Chinese still have bad voice-acting, but thats no negative). Social persuasion was a part of the interaction with key characters as well as in the storyline. I'll admit, some of the conversations to convince somebody got pretty intense; hearing what they have to say in response to your own.\n\nThe Combat is an interesting place to address. The mechanics are largely successful in allowing varied gameplay across the missions. If you want to stealth, there are ways to stealth. If you want to be Rambo, you can be Rambo (just expect a bit tougher experience). While going Rambo can get you through a mission, the game rewards the player for being ghostly"
date: or not detected by the enemy. The maps and locations gave many different approaches to get to an objective or in a firefight. Vents are sometimes seen in walls to allow the hiding of bodies or escaping from fight heat.\n\nThe vast array of augmentations allows the player to shape Adam Jensen into the character you feel comfortable playing as. One of the things I liked about the augmentation system is that it didn't force any down your throat. When you collect Praxis Kits for augmentation upgrades
recommended: you have the choice to apply them or not. An interesting game playthrough worth considering is a No-Aug run
hoursPlayed: where you never upgrade (out of the thoughts of Jensen's aug-opinions).\n\nOverall
helpfulPercent: I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys story-driven gameplay and well-executed stealth mechanics. Combining engrossing storyline with gameplay mechanics and player-choice
votesHelpful: I rate this game a 9.5/10."

reviewText: It's pretty good, there are alwyas a few hiccups with graphics and what not. But no game is perfect.\nThat being said, it's really good if you like a more sci-fi based splinter cell. The world is interactive and it's a great buy. The story gets you involved immensely, with different ways of approaching  each situation, there is a degree of replayability.  You can go in like rambo, or go stealthy, or a combination of both. In the long run, your choices changes your gameplay experience. Whether you choose to help someone, or you come across in an arrogant manner to a character, it all affects the way the game feels. Good buy, I would buy when on sale, 20$ seems a bit much.

Don't let the nay sayers persuade you to not get this version.  This is a more complete game and yes there may be bugs, but I've not recently discovered them.  I own the original on PS3 first, then bought the original on PC and then got Missing Link.  When I found that this game has both in one complete game, it makes it worth while to own it.  Because Missing Link was like a separate entity, this version keeps it all in-game and that's why I bought it.  So forget the folks out there cutting this game down.  I knew what I was getting when I bought it, and I have no regrets.
This game has waltzed it's way right into my favorite games of all time list and I very highly recommend that you play it.

only scratched the surface of this game, and already it's like an addiction. With a gamescape that is like walking into the world of Bladerunner, the mix of futuristic afluency, high-tech augs and the search for immortality, mixed with street thugs, filth ridden alleyway quests with insight into some criminal underworld, all works so well to create this dystopian future, where technology is loved and hated, needed and abused to be used as a weapon against it's own creators. All we need now is a Tyrell  Corp. and a selfsacrificng Batty to make us question our own morality.

reviewText:
I have played Deus ex Human Revolution on my Ps3 for a long time and in the summer sales of steam i saw this offer for just 5 euros and I just knew I had to buy this upgraded version of Deus ex Human Revolution, but the question for me is, is this upgraded version worth it or not.

To start of with, Deus ex Human Revolution is a very good game that lets you play whatever way you want to play, if its stealth, more violent or a mix between both or even without killing anyone, you can play all those ways and lots more. This gives it a lot of replay value ( at least for me). The stealth system is pretty well done, i've seen better stealth games but it's still a great stealth game, the more violent way of playing isn't the great part of this game as its not really enjoyable at least if you play it on the hardest difficulty. The story is superb and I love how this is a openworld game but still linear. Oberall the normal version of this game is for me one of the best game of the last 3 years and i would highly suggest it.

Now the question is, is this marveallous game worth it if you already own the normal version, firs of all if you havent played this game yet I highly recommend you buy this version and not the normal version because it also includes the dlc. This upgraded version comes with 3 mayor upgrades: first it includes the dlc, second it has the developers commentary which I find highly entertaining and it just gives you more depth in the game and thirt boss fights can be done stealthly. It also upgrades a bit the graphics and some game mechanics. I recommend this version if you dont own th dlc, but if you dont own it  recommend it because of the dlc and developers commentary because it gives your new playthrough more depth at the cost of just 5 euros.

I find this version superior to the normal version and a must have on your gaming library

Highly addictive, if you are a fan of the first or Anachronox or into cyber punk themed worlds, this game won't dissapoint. It has good replay value as well as refined controls, RPG and game changing elements similar to Mass Effect and lots of side quests. Lighting and textures have changed slightly over the original version and the integration of The Missing Link DLC is now more streamlined. Only negative side would be a few bugs that aren't addressed for this version that the original has already addressed through patches which is an awkward move by the developers, but based on the recent patch in november 2013 and a few posts on Eidos' forums, the technical team are listening to the fans in hopes of getting this game bug free. Otherwise an A+ title for everyone to enjoy.

An amazing game on all fronts. Great game play and level desgn leaving for the player to choose three ways to tackle each objective. Throughout the game you will be put against challenges where the only limitation is the skills that you have at the time. My major gripe against the game is that the boss fights are unchanged. Even though it was promised they would be rebalanced for stealth, each of the bosses were kept to shooting them to death. It is possible to do non-lethal kills but it still goes down to shotting a bullet sponge. Although this does not detract from an over all enjoyable experience.

While this game doesn't deliver as the original did back in the Days,it isn't a quick and uninspired cashgrab either (looking at you,Syndicate reboot which wasn't good at all).

Your choiced matter and there are always multiple ways to approach something,the artstyle is fantastic & once the Game got you sucked into it,you never want it to end.

If you're in for the PewPewPew you might get a bit disappointed because the gunplay isn't that good,taking people out in hand to hand combat is very well done tho.All in all,i would suggest giving that game a go if you are into Cyberpunk,DeusEx or stealth gameplay in general.

The original release was one of the best games of 2011, hands down. It has a deep, rich storyline and setting that fans of cyberpunk--from Blade Runner to Ghost in the Shell--will greatly appreciate. The gameplay is smooth and challenging, and players of games such as Metal Gear Solid, Mass Effect, Thief, and the original Deus Ex will find themselves right at home with this fantastic title.

With the Director's Cut, a few changes and additions have been made. The most notable of these are the inclusion of the DLC missions into the main campaign--the Missing Link is no longer a separate game--the improved boss fights, and the developer commentary. There were other minor changes, but many players may not notice these. The inclusion of the Missing Link chapter helps round out the storyline, as well as give the player the opportunity to redo his or her skill points, which was something missing from the original 2011 release.

The improved boss fights were appreciated, though the additional avenues of defeating the bosses will still take some quick thinking, or trial and error, to truly take advantage. For fans that want a more balanced approach to the game, where any style of play is rewarded, this is the edition to purchase.

Developer commentary in this version of the game is an interesting and valuable addition. It can be toggled on or off at the player's convenience, and many of the nodes offer intriguing insight into the minds of the game's creators. The only minor irritations with the commentary involve the nodes themselves. They are not always apparent in the game world, and once a node is playing it cannot be stopped without going into the main menu options and toggling the commentary off. Still, in spite of that minor oversight, the commentary is exciting to listen to and veteran players will appreciate it.

I highly recommend that new and old fans of Deus Ex: Human Revolution grab a copy of the Director's Cut.

reviewText: One of the best RPG's possibly ever. Set in a dystopian near-future with an amazing story and great execution, Deus Ex- HR delivers what Invisible War couldn't. it's a great game with many different ways of finishing your objectives, Very well optimised and with the Director's cut redone where the original had hiccups - such as the boss fights, I definetly and whole-heartedly recommend this game to anyone wanting a sci-fi story that grips you from start to finish packed into a game that's fun to play and replay.

Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a prequel to Deus Ex and is the third game in the series. The main features of the game are true to their expectations, allowing you multiple ways to handle missions, varied upgrade choices and enough side stories to keep you engaged in the world around you. An explorer is rewarded as are compleitionists for the multiple difficulty settings and achievements they can receive like no kills, no detection (ghosting) and no alarms. If you waited for the discounts and all dlc included be sure to pick this up if you like Thief style genres. My only critique would be remembering  the promise of additional cities during pre-release hype but it still has enough content to be worth your steam dollars.

Oh, where to begin?  Deux Ex is a decent game, blending concepts of stealth, shooting, and social engineering.  Unfortunately, it doesn't really excel in any area.  The stealth sequences are very old-fashioned, in that they work well enough if you choose to stay concealed but fall apart badly if you prefer to kill quietly.  The shooting mechanics are hindered by poor controls - left trigger dives for cover instead of aiming down sights, etc - and by guns that just don't feel good.  It's great that the weapons can be upgraded in all manner of ways, but it's all for naught if they don't feel good to shoot.  Case in point: the round from a sniper rifle shouldn't drop in flight by 18 inches during a 25 yard shot.  Also, a guy that gets hit in the head with a finger-long projectile traveling at roughly 700 mph shouldn't immediately snap to attention and try to figure out who shot him just because he's wearing a helmet.  Finally, the parts of the game that attempt to challenge players by way of dialogue choices feels like LA Noire - the clues and responses that you're given don't correspond very tightly to the desired outcomes; two players making the same choices won't necessarily get the same result - it's stupid.\n\nAll that said, the game features an intriguing story and is good enough (barely) at what it does to be worth playing.  The director's cut (poorly) incorporates the Missing Link DLC into the main campaign and adds some optional DVD-style commentary.  Unfortunately, because the upgrade exists as a separate title in the Steam library no saved games or achievements carry over into the new game.  I'd say that it's worth grabbing, but only if you don't already own The Missing Link.

reviewText:
I have played Deus ex Human Revolution on my Ps3 for a long time and in the summer sales of steam i saw this offer for just 5 euros and I just knew I had to buy this upgraded version of Deus ex Human Revolution, but the question for me is, is this upgraded version worth it or not.

To start of with, Deus ex Human Revolution is a very good game that lets you play whatever way you want to play, if its stealth, more violent or a mix between both or even without killing anyone, you can play all those ways and lots more. This gives it a lot of replay value ( at least for me). The stealth system is pretty well done, i've seen better stealth games but it's still a great stealth game, the more violent way of playing isn't the great part of this game as its not really enjoyable at least if you play it on the hardest difficulty. The story is superb and I love how this is a openworld game but still linear. Oberall the normal version of this game is for me one of the best game of the last 3 years and i would highly suggest it.

Now the question is, is this marveallous game worth it if you already own the normal version, firs of all if you havent played this game yet I highly recommend you buy this version and not the normal version because it also includes the dlc. This upgraded version comes with 3 mayor upgrades: first it includes the dlc, second it has the developers commentary which I find highly entertaining and it just gives you more depth in the game and thirt boss fights can be done stealthly. It also upgrades a bit the graphics and some game mechanics. I recommend this version if you dont own th dlc, but if you dont own it  recommend it because of the dlc and developers commentary because it gives your new playthrough more depth at the cost of just 5 euros.

I find this version superior to the normal version and a must have on your gaming library

DISCLAIMER: Don't get fooled by many negative reviews, most of them compare Director's Cut to the original. Original, however, doesn't seem to be available on Steam anymore, so if you've never played it, this is your best (and only) chance!

Now, let's get on with the review.

Never played Human Revolution? - Get it!
Already played HR, should I get Director's Cut? - Got money to spare? Want trading cards/badges? Missed DLC? Sure, go for it. Otherwise, not really.

Pros
- amazing story
- dialogue and other choices have effects later on
- you can choose stealth and not kill a single enemy or go on an all-out killing spree. You can also combine those two approaches
- multiple solutions to various situations
- custom select your abilities (augmentations) to fit your playstyle
- a lot of playtime for purely single-player experience (first playthrough is likely going to take you 20-30 hours, how many single-player games offer that nowadays?)


Cons
- a lot of moving between objectives and your sprinting doesn't last all that long
(Wow, that's all I could come up with. I may add some more later but right now, I can't seem to think of anything else that could bother someone. Note: See the Differences section below for potential cons)


Differences between regular and Director's Cut [+/-]
+ re-worked bossfights, making them less harsh on players who choose stealth
+ integrated DLC
- colors seem washed out, can be fixed with ENB
- may encounter some performance issues and/or bugs. Personally, I didn't notice any but maybe I'm just lucky.

When my friend bought this game for me, it was 7pm on a Friday. When I stopped playing, it was 3am on Saturday. This game might not be the best game out there, the controls can be subpar at times, and the story can be extremely convoluted and boring to those who are not into the setting, but by god, this game is IMMERSIVE. If you can let yourself get lost in the environment and the story, and the characters, and everything else good about this game, you'll feel as though you're just there, that the game itself is reality. It's glorius, and I highly reccommend that even people who aren't a big fan of the pseudo-stealth cover-based first-person shooter genre should check it out for immersion alone.

Sneaked, stunned and hacked my way through the first half of the game, gun totted without remorse through the rest of it. Though the former was more bountiful xp and augmentation-wise, the latter was definitely more fun. Gotta love emptying a heavy rifle barrel on a handful of unsuspecting cronies while cloaked.

Does feel kind of engineered when you realize that all the various approaches(hack security, hidden passages, social, brute) are available for the vast majority of objectives.

Engrossing world & storyline. Highly recommended.

Pros
1. Allowed to switch to third person mode when using cover.
2. Do not like stealthy approach ? Then set up the chaos as you wish !

3. Cool animation for action, eg. shock wave, numerous of brutal melee take down with augmented hands !
4.Invisibility like in Crysis 3 !

5. Dialogue in selctive options to make different choices and to achieve different outcomes. Like Mass Effect 3 !
6. Over 50 hours of campaign ( completionist + leisure , no rushing play style )

7. Wall hack vision like Batman !
8. Computer hacking !

9. China Cities and Chinese folks that talk in Mandarine !
10. Alternate way to approach your target location, more than Crysis did !

11. Decent story and very responsive AI / NPC

Cons
1. Limited inventory, cannot carrry all weapons.

2. The game expect you to stick with a the same weapon, if you wish to keep the new weapon, then you need to drop and forgo one of the upgraded weapon, as there are no garage or place to keep your, at least in Borderlans game, there is a garage to keep old weapon that u do not want to dispose yet.

3. Limited Mods for weapon upgrades, if u missed out to collect or buy from certain location, then you have no chance to buy back the previous mods again. Eg. there are total of 6 Damage mods available in game, and there are numerous weapon allowed to upgrade damage stats, if you missed out the 2 mods , then you only left 4 chances to upgrade later on.

4. It was a pain to forgo a almost fully upgradeed weapon to swtich for a new unlocked weapon, because there is limited capacity in your inventory and no garage available to keep weapons.

5. Most side missions were bland.

Overall verdict  -->    8  / 10

A fantastic Cyberpunk RPG. While your actions in a given quest don't have the biggest impact on the overall story, the freedom and possible resolutions available within any given quest is pretty impressive. Gameplay is pretty solid; it's slower and more tactical than your average shooter, but it's executed well and blends great with the tone of the game world.\n\nThe Director's Cut has some great improvements over the original, the most notable being turning off the Jarate filter, redesigning the boss fights to allow for a variety of approaches instead of forcing you into cover-shooting regardless of what your playstyle thus far was, and including the expansion as an in-built portion of the story.
An excellent game.... outstanding story and high replay value......

I have never been so immersed into a video game before, and enjoyed every minute of playing Deus Ex.
Deux Ex has the coolest and most interesting universe and plots of any game I have played, portraying a very believable and frightening future of a world in moral conflict and on the brink of civil war.
The combat revolves around the player taking either a stealth approach or an aggresive one. Either way being fun, leaving players wanting to redo a checkpoint to perfect a certain method to complete it.
This kind of gameplay has innevitably resulted in AI being a bit stuipid and too oblivious at times. Additionally, some boss fights are bit over the top and unnesccary.
However, the variety of skills the player has to choose from and the unique environments of each chapter/level overshadows these faults.
Deus Ex has been an example and of why games should be taken more seriously, and have alot more potential than being viewed as violent shoot em ups' as seen in the past.

reviewText: One of the best RPG's possibly ever. Set in a dystopian near-future with an amazing story and great execution, Deus Ex- HR delivers what Invisible War couldn't. it's a great game with many different ways of finishing your objectives, Very well optimised and with the Director's cut redone where the original had hiccups - such as the boss fights, I definetly and whole-heartedly recommend this game to anyone wanting a sci-fi story that grips you from start to finish packed into a game that's fun to play and replay.

Deus Ex Human Revolution resonated with every fibre of my being when i first played it way back in 2011. The Director's Cut has the original plus all the dlc and is only $5 if you own the original therefore buying it is a no-brainer. One of the best Sci Fi / Cyberpunk games out there. The story is very rich and engaging, filled with great writing and with a great theme of transhumanism. Its also very visually appealing, with a cyber renaissance aesthetic that looks just gorgeus. Gameplay is amazing, with a mix of stealth and exploration and if you want to, some action. The directors cut also includes a creator commentary, which is just a ton of fun to listen to, if you are into that stuff. You learn alot about the development of the game, and about the content which was cut from the final version of the game.

Okay so I really liked this game and to make my review very short I want to mention that the game has a lot more good than bad.

Pros

-Amazing Graphics
-Long and engaging story
- Action/ stealth play
-Power ups
-Exploration
- Difficult if you like that sort of thing.

Cons

The game has only a few cons which are.

-Weapons should be upgradable more often given you stronger weapons and not needing a dealer.
-Not many unique sidequests (mostly just going into peoples apartmets and beating them up which is actually a lot of fun but not a lot of variety).
-Shooting mechanics can be a little tighter and allow for controller adjustment (Played with an xbox 360 controller)
-Exploration is limited to areas in a city that are not anywher near the vast expansion of Skyrim and other like games.


Overal go ahead and get it its worth the money and you will have fun playing it. The Steam sale does allow you to get it for super cheap but its worth getting for 20 I originally bought it for xbox 360 for 70, Did not beat it until I re bought it for steam.

I never finished the 'vanilla' version of DXHR as I lost patience by the second boss battle, despite a well crafted experience fitting of the first game.

Glad to say that this 'directors cut' adequately fixes the jarring boss battles, as well as seamlessly adding all the DLC packs and additional 'Missing Link' content into the full game. This more than makes up for the orignal game's failings.

My only annoyance, and this stands for the first game was the jarring completely different final section that puts you into a completely different stuation. All makes sense plotwise, but from a gameplay perspective, a bit of a jump.

Still, this 'director's cut' is well worth a go, especially if you missed out back in 2011.

Awesome stealth game. I like that you can move freely in the world, kill anyone (And I really mean anyone, even the police or random people on the street). I was asked for this! Absolutely fantastic. This is a phenomenal game. Playing the original is not required at all to understand the story, but I do suggest playing it simply because its a great game. I think that any gamer should try this game at least one time!

I absolutely love and recommend this game. A great job was done with it. Great storyline and a non linear playing experience just like the previous Deus Ex games. Combines FPS and RPG in a seamless manner. Many elements of the very first Deus Ex game are present in this title.

If you've played the non-Director's Cut version, this is better. If you haven't played DE:HR, get this version. It's wonderful to have a non-Valve game with developer commentary while playing it. While I found the Missing Link DLC (included as part of this version) to be tedious back-and-forth over the same fairly boring maze of maps, although it has a decent story, the rest of the game is either as good or better than the original. The definitive version of an amazing game. I rarely if ever replay an entire game, but I don't regret at all replaying this one.

well done game in general. although i can say if you just run and gun through the whole game you miss alot of the elements that make it a great game, ive been doing a ghost pasifst run, and i can say i am truly impressed with the depth to the mutiple choice conversations adam jenson can have.  over all good visuals, good gameplay with options and nice yellow colour scheme

Simply put, its a story that is complicated yet knows how to pulls things for a comprehensive story and a strong central theme about what it means to be human and human transfiguration. The graphics are well enough but the art design is what makes the world unique and special. The gameplay is open for loud gunplay or stealthy neck breaking in a elegant combination of the mechanics. Its everything I could ask of a open-world game, being open to many possibile gameplay styles and choices while also having compelling characters and a story line that doesn't get water downed by the scope of the open world. Whole-heartedly recommend to all my gaming friends.

A little harder to run that the original vertion but still a great game. Looks like all of the oringinal shortcomeing were worked out.

Goes on sale for $5 often and if you owned the original+dlc you can buy it for $5 at any time I believe.

Well worth it.

The Director's Cut offers some enhancements over the original version as well as Developers Commentary and Making of footage. Among the new features are the improvements in Boss Fight where you are not limited or forced to front armed combat, and the integration of The Missing Link DLC.
Putting the Director's Cut tag to a side, and having played on Normal, I must admit I was faced with one of the dumbest AI. The story, clichéd as it is, it's also interesting enough to get you hooked the whole game. Controls are awkward as shooting mechanics, but once you get used to them it becomes a much enjoyable experience.
Graphics are very nice, and characters are coupled with good quality voice acting, but it's in the music department where this title really shines. Character levelling and the choices you make give replayability to the different stages and situations.
In short, nothing too outstanding, but in spite of it's flaws I still recommend this game. After all, it's surely in the top 10 of AAA titles of the year.

reviewText:
THIS REVIEW HAS BEEN WRITTEN IN 2015!!
One of the best games i've ever played!

Graphics: 8/10 (It's from 2013 though. Would be 10/10 in 2013 though!)
Gameplay: 8/10 - There are so many options to complete the game! From Stealth - to massmurderer
Sound: 10/10 - Really good ''high-tec''-like sounds that do fit in the setting.
Atmosphere: 10/10 - Great future-environment with high-tec Robot-enemys, augmented humans and ''light in darkness''-kind of tone
Difficulty-Settings: 10/10 - Couldn't get any better when it comes to difficulty-settings of your gameplay!


Conclusion:
A really good game! Gameplay is enjoable and interesting with all the upgrading-systems and RPG elements that you can't put any better into an ego-shooter. Story is really ''Realistic'' and dark, but good! You are able to decide how the story keeps going on and it has a really big impact. Definetely a must-have-played for every ego/RPG/Story - Gamer!

Enjoyable FPS stealth infiltration game with light RPG elements. Gameplay reminded me of Splinter Cell but with robotic enhancements.  Credible lead character nicely voiced in a Clint Eastwood style clenched teeth drawl.  Essentially you play as this maverick  Cyber-Dirty Harry  ex-cop trying to get to the truth behind the attack on the Biotech company that employs you as the head of security.  OK story, light RPG, main mission focused, limited number of side missions.  Oh and one more thing, it's good to play as a character you actually like and who isn't  a complete !?£$.  Bought it on sale 80% off, good value, worth it.

It's one of those very few games that are mixing together different gameplay elements in the right way.
Deus Ex is a Stealth-RPG-FPS-Action lore heavy game. It is really standing out in every aspect and everything is executed in the right way.
The story is great, varied, with many twists. The characters are memorable, layered, the conversations feel very natural, the writing is awesome.
There are many moral choices and all lead to different conclusions. There are different endings and overall the lore of the game is somewhat ironically feels like it's pointing the finger to our real world. You will see some of teh best looking endings in gaming history.
The gameplay is polished, the rpg elements are simple to understand and well implemented.
Yous simply have everything here... Queasts, sidequests, different collectibles, reading materials. You can solve missions in many ways, somewhat reminding you of games like the Hitman series just in a Cyberpunk enviroment. Yep you can be like Hulk, Rambo, Leon the professional, or Sam Fisher to tackle your missions, using your enviroment in many different ways.
I strongly recomend this game to any gamer regardless of what type of game you like to play, it feels like there si something and everything for anyone here.

reviewText: Don't buy the hype about old game engines and bugs. I bought game on sale around christmas and game ran smooth on max settings throughout. A very solid game, amazing story, etc. I def recommend this one.

Bought the game when it was on offer and I have to say that this game is very good. You have the option to either kill the enemies like a killing machine(literally) or sneak around like a ninja. Difficulty is okay at first and then they slowly raise it as you unlock more and more augmentations, and some parts require you to think hard and make use of the objects in your environment if you want to be a ninja. Boss fights are interspersed at appropriate intervals, so even ninjas have a chance to kill. Stealth in this game can sometimes be an adrenaline rush and hacking wise, I have to say that I find it interesting, especially when you hack higher level terminals. Outside of story missions, you can roam the streets and pick up side quests as well hack into everything you see that has a security terminal, making the game not just limited to main missions, but allowing you to explore and also get achievements. All in all, a 9/10 and I really highly recommend this game if you are willing to dedicate the time to explore the areas of the game.\n\nP.S: Have not finished the game yet but these are my thoughts so far. Feel free to refer to other reviews if you want more info.

This game is truly fantastic. Many have conflicting views on it's quality, but I believe truly that, having played the original game, its faults can be treated as homages to DX1, for instance, the poor sight range of npc AI. The overall art style is fantastic, and one I am still reeling at years after it's creation. I solidly believe that this game is a must-play for any who are a fan of RPGs or Sci-Fi action games.

I had a lot of fun with this game. I had a few technical issues playing it on my system, but nothing I couldn't get around. The levels were interesting and there is certainly some significant replay value to it since you can play the character in so many different ways.

Play full stealth or go in guns blazing or a combination and  it was a blast. The game allows you to play through without having to kill anyone (except boss battles), it's all up to your gaming style and personality.

A must have IMHO. :)

Before playing this Game, I had never been interested or even a follower of the Deus Ex series. This game changed that. Deus Ex Human Revolution is by far one of my favorite games of all time. The pure aspect of the game being a game almost without a genre is appealing to me. The reason I say a game without a genre, is because the game is open, and literally can be played anyway you want. The progression is stellar, both gameplay and storyline wise. The other thing I like about this game is just how open it is. For example, I had to get into a bar to talk to one of the contacts helping me with a mission, there unfortunately was a bouncer outside who wouldn't let me in. I looked for other entrances, and found one but I had to move a dumpster, and my strength wasn't high enough to move it to let me in, hence I pick up another side mission promising me more piraxis points to level up so then I can revisit the club and continue with my story mission. This is the reason why this game is great, there are literally so many different ways and possibilities of completing your mission it warrant multiple play throughs. On top of all of this, the storyline is fantastic, personally I love the voice acting of Adam Jensen (Elias Toufexious) and his grizzled demenour, and the stroyline is just so thick and rich filled with twists and turns and questions, its a very well put together game. Gameplay, Storyline, and Pacing are some of the things that make this great. I can't wait to see what they'll do in the sequel. The only cons I would list, are that the game isn't the prettiest, I understand this was made a couple years ago, but for example Adam Jensen's hair in game just looks atrocious. Only improvement I would request in the sequel.
If you are a fan of Tech Noir, Cyberpunk, or anything along those lines... then, yeah, you should play this.

(For those of you wondering whether this is a version of Human Revolution with Montreal and/or Upper Hengsha city hubs: sorry, this isn't it.  At this point, I doubt it'll ever come our way, at least barring a Super Director's Cut" edition.  Don't be waiting for it.)\n\nThe DE:HR Director's Cut integrates The Missing Link

reviewText: Although heavily plagued with game-breaking bugs, this combined role-playing cloak-and-carbine first person shooter really revives, revamps, and reconstructs every single criterion that defined the timeless Deus Ex series. Well-designed stealth system, choice of non-lethal pacifism or brutal kill-everyone gameplay, extreme dark dystopian Gattaca+Bladerunner style speculative fiction setting, easy-to-control COD style weapon aiming, cyborg-level customisable character leveling, and most importantly the power to manipulate the entire plot, storyline, boss-fight conditions and final outcome implicitly and cumulatively via emotionally-intensive multiple-choice dialogues throughout each mission. As the title indicates, this game really tests the limits of what it means to be human" philosophically. +1337 points for  actually calling the antagonists The Illuminati.\nILLUMINATI CONFIRMED."

Deus Ex Human Revolution is certainly a game worth having, and while the directors cut took a graphical hit, it is still a high quality game. DXHR is a tactical first person stealth shooter with several RPG elements. Like the original, DXHR encourages player choice with many branching paths all of which lead you to your objective. You could blast your way through guards, hack into and shut down the security, or simply hop in an air duct and avoid everything. However, the choices arent balanced which leads to one of the only issues the game faces. There is no incentive to fighting the bad guys. While there is choice, the game does lead towards the stealth option which has you crawling through ducts and sneaking around the perimeter of the map. However, that doesn't make the game any less satisfying. Avoiding all guards and cameras is every bit as fun as gunning through a room full of guards.

Another stregnth of the game is the preogression system. The augmentations are all useful and unique. Each one will give you a very useful tool against your enemies and as a result, the progression system is as rewarding as it could be.

DXHR also benefits from a engaging and well written story which is aided by a superb soundtrack and top-notch voice acting. The story has you, Adam Jensen, traveling around the world in search of the people who led an attack on the Sarif Industries lab months earlier. The narrative never lets up and will keep you searching for the truth all the way through. All in all, DXHR is a worthing prequel the the original Deus Ex, and is worth having.

This game is one of the best games I have played. Anyways onto the gameplay

The gameplay is a tps-fps stealth hybrid. Its a hybrid in a sense that you can go into every level or map guns blazing or you can sneak in take-out a few guards silently and complete the objectives wihout tripping the alarm. Each playstyle has its +s and -s but it really only suits to the player's choice.

The story in the game is by far one of the best played because it all makes sense but leaves you guessing like a really good mystery movie mixed with blade runner. It can keep you on the edge of the seat while making you feel for the main characters and how ♥♥♥♥ed up the world is.

all in all I really really really enjoy this game and I would recomend it to anyone looking for a fun experience!

I played this game right after completing Dark Souls 2, and all I wanted was to play a FPS title. When I first started the game, I felt that the controls and interface was rather clunky. While the controls can be remapped in the menu, you would have to slowly get used to the interface, such as how to hack, how to upgrade your gear when you level up, and cleaning your inventory.

The story mainly revolves around the ethics of augmentations, that being when technology advances and when people have the ability to modify their own body (even their mind) such that they function better. This extends beyond mere prostheses for the disabled such as protagonist Adam Jensen, but also willing modifications on perfectly fine bodies. While the benefits are apparant, those who oppose come forward with arguments such as the misuse in crimes or the alteration of oneself away from the image of God.

What really attracts me is how the game is open to multiple gameplay approaches. As mentioned, I started the game wanting an FPS, so I went in guns-blazing killing everything I see. Halfway through, I started to incorporate stealth after upgrading specific augmentations and in the end, the game offered me an ending that defined my time as Adam Jensen. There are a total of 12 unique endings and in the one I got, Adam says and I quote: Technologies are invented to make our lives easier -- not our choices. The problem comes when we forget that.

9/10

reviewText: A first person action RPG with an excellent story and tons of customization and dialogue choices, not to mention several paths to completion for your objectives whether you like the stealth or guns blazing approach.

Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a great game. Why? Because it serves its purpose of making you choose how you'd like to play. From stealthing your way through a whole section, taking down badguys behind every corner, or going guns blazing- killing every one in sight; it's one of those games where choice is present. Although there may be choice, it does not affect your character or story (unfortunately). I played through this game twice and had fun playing it over again just to get the achievements.

The game itself has a wonderful story; one that opens its way into the earlier Deus Ex games. There are plenty of easter eggs from the previous game to be found here since this is chronologically a prequel to the other Deus Ex games. It was definitely thrilling towards the end where different endings appeared. I saved it at the time to make sure I went across each ending and those endings gave the game justice. I couldn't stop the goosebumps from popping out.

All in all, if there ever was a chance to get Deus Ex:HR - get it. Make sure it's the Director's Cut too because then you'd have the DLC (Missing Link) implemented in as well as for a few more added features. If not, just get the game regardless.

With over 200 hours between this updated version and the original plus Missing Link DLC, I've thoroughly enjoyed this game and would recommend it to people that enjoy stealth based games.  Of course, you can decide to use guns and go in blazing, but it's not as satisfying as watcing Adam take them down silently.  Along with stealth combat, you can hack computers, terminals, gun turrents, etc., talk people into giving up information that they normally would not, and the game adds RPG elements in the form of perks or skills.  Even when I thought that 5 or 6 playthroughs were not enough on the hardest difficulty, I still come back to this game for some more ♥♥♥♥ kicking.  It never gets old knocking people out.
If you like orange filters and crawling through air ducts, this is the game for you.
I love this game. Let this game into your heart!

I did not know Deus Ex before i saw it on Steam. I purchased this game because it was on sale, cost only $4.99. I watch some trailers and reviews reckoned i could give it a shot. And gladly its worth the money.

For starters, this game is somewhat like Mass effect + Dishonored hybrid, assuming you know both these games. You might not agree, anyways its just my opinion. But be warned, to me this isint quite a shooter game. It's an FPS, it has got a handful of guns and you can shoot things as shown in the trailer but most of the times you'll be doing lots of stealth, hiding behind covers trying to sneak past enemies. Sounds pretty familiar? (Hitman). Well if you dont like the stealth approach, you could go gun blazing, but i dont think this is the way this game is meant to be played, especially during the first half of the story which is after llike 10+ hours of gameplay (for me) mainly because you could be easily outgunned. Of course you could jump right infront of the enemies and shoot them in the face tough later in the game prior to sufficent upgrade of your carecter.

So..... If you are looking for fast-paced shooter like COD, your wont get it. Its a slow-paced game involved lots of thinking as in how do i get past this, how do i access that, something like that. If you're in it for the story telling and RPG experience then i recommend you to grab it. The voice acting might not be fantastic but it works and it surely gave me a somewhat unique experience that not many games could offer.

I'd love to give it a 9/10 but -1 for the graphics/visuals, so it's 8/10 ! Dont get me wrong, its graphics aren't crappy at all, is just that i adore better ones.

I've played through this game three times. The last because I bought the Director's cut but this goes to show you what Square has done with this title! I don't spend time on games much these days but this is one of those games that you will for sure do so, without regrets. The replayability is great and gives you the chance to do some things differently or not at all. Also makes boss battles on the hardest difficulty a breeze when you know what to upgrade in which order (hint: Typhoon). Anytime this is on sale (or even not) this is a worthy title to house in your library. Game direction, music and control are fantastic. Run n' gun or stealth: your choice! Buy it!

I have never been so immersed into a video game before, and enjoyed every minute of playing Deus Ex.
Deux Ex has the coolest and most interesting universe and plots of any game I have played, portraying a very believable and frightening future of a world in moral conflict and on the brink of civil war.
The combat revolves around the player taking either a stealth approach or an aggresive one. Either way being fun, leaving players wanting to redo a checkpoint to perfect a certain method to complete it.
This kind of gameplay has innevitably resulted in AI being a bit stuipid and too oblivious at times. Additionally, some boss fights are bit over the top and unnesccary.
However, the variety of skills the player has to choose from and the unique environments of each chapter/level overshadows these faults.
Deus Ex has been an example and of why games should be taken more seriously, and have alot more potential than being viewed as violent shoot em ups' as seen in the past.
