Deus Ex: Human Revolution has one of the most interesting and involved plotlines I have seen in a game for a long time. It keeps throwing new things at you every twist and turn, but it doesn't feel like it's just pulling things out of its ♥♥♥. For once in a game, I felt legitimately motivated to seek out and perform sidequests, just to see how they would be presented as a story. The journey was fantastic, but the destination was rather lacking. I'm dissapointed that this game, which always pointed out the difference between lethal and non-lethal means of taking enemies down, only had 4 standard endings. All of which literally involved a choice of one of three buttons or saying f*ck it and destroying everything around you. There are no differences for playing incredibly lethally or sneaking around and not killing anyone.\n\nSpeaking of sneaking, it is one of the hardest things to do in this game during later levels. reviewText: Stealth. Stealth. Stealth. Fun. Fun. Fun.\n\nSneaking around and using your powers in this game is alot of fun. The shooting mehanics are good too, but it's so much fun to see if you can get through a mission without being detected. The story is also solid. A must buy if you like stealth games.
Great game.

Pros
- Breathtaking story
- Fluid gameplay
- No need to play others to understand the storyline since game itself covers it ( I recommend playing it tho )
- Adam's voice
- One of a kind soundtrack ( Only Witcher and Mass Effect can go head to head from new genre rpg )
- High replay value, 2 plays at least one steath one rambo
- Lots of emotional moments
- Map design for missions are superb, you don't feel repetitive
- Director's Cut brings commentary which may help newcomers pass certain areas without searching for guides
- Can achieve certain things that require augmentation with quick thinking
Cons
- City designs are average, you want to skip right to action without walking around too much
- Long cutscenes which can't be skipped can be boring during replays
- DLC missions happens in a totaly seperate map which demans you to walk in circles basicly
- DLC area loading time is annoying
- Not much to do in your home
- Mirror in the bathroom of your home still broken after DLC ( fix it damn it )
- I never asked for this.
Conclusion

One of the MUST know games of the gaming history. If you don't agree with me just watch the opening cinematic from youtube. You'll thank me later.

DE:HR is a fantastic experience with enjoyable writing and acting, mature themes and some of the coolest art direction I’ve seen. My main disappointment is how it motivates you to play in a very narrow way (a certain stealth approach); rendering all of the cool gadgets you collect null. I’ll explain later.

The game throws you right into the middle of things, and you need to pay attention to understand who’s who and what’s what. There’s no slow prologue telling how the world came to be in the state it is and how you find yourself there. It's something I like, because it helps establish this sense of realism that sticks throughout the entire game - that this is an actual world, not dependent on your existence to continue moving. You are part of it, not the center of it. Still, I’ll help you with the basic orientation.

You’re Adam Jensen, former SWAT and currently chief of security at a biotech company, that is at the forefront of human augmentation (mechanical upgrades to humans) research and development. You are an existing and set character, not a blank slate, so the choices you make are limited to what is reasonable for Adam to do. Many people enjoy creating their characters out of scratch. This is not that kind of game. Personally, I prefer this format. It’s a fine balance that offers some amount of input, but not too much to the point that it sacrifices the depth of the story just to give you more choices that end up being shallow. Speaking of which, the consequences of your decisions are also pleasantly felt later on. I didn't find them to be too drastic, but the small nods were satisfying nevertheless.

Augmentation is the main topic the world is embroiled in at 2027, and the debate about its pros and cons extends to ethical, political, economical and social aspects. It’s a nice take on sci-fi that manages to keep things still relatively grounded and credible, while also enjoying some creative liberties where the developers wanted to emphasize the subject. Suspension of disbelief is required in some places more than others, but overall the game manages to sell a believable, alternate world. And it’s a bleak one. Earth is in the midst of a cyber renaissance, but once you move away from the socialites to the streets and alleyways, you will feel an atmosphere that is opposite from the optimistic aura of revolution that is present among the upper class. The change the world is going through isn’t embraced by all, doesn’t grace all, and there is an obvious tension in the air. The title of the next game is Mankind Divided, but the hints and seeds of that segregation are already found here.

The progression through levels is linear. While you revisit some of them, they’re in a changed state, and you can never go back to a level you’ve finished. They’re divided into the regular hub areas you know from most RPGs – open areas for your exploration to restock, talk with people, do side quests, etc – and the hostile levels that are much more fight or stealth oriented. Less talk, more action.

Augmentations are the source of your abilities, and they’re varied enough to make leveling up an exciting occurrence. DE:HR isn't plagued by endless passive upgrades (e.g. 4% damage increase) that leave you with nothing to look forward to. You have plenty of enhancements that are new abilities, which allow you to do things you couldn’t previously achieve. There’s an interesting dialogue system that triggers with certain, important NPCs. One augmentation helps you better analyze these key figures to find the correct answer. Hacking is everywhere, and the mini-game that seems confusing at first turns out to be simple and fun. You can choose to jump higher to reach new areas, punch through weak walls or move heavy objects to open additional routes. And on the RPG note, you even have an old-school inventory system that forces you to choose what to take and what to ditch. Weapons or stealth equipment? You can't have everything.

All these abilities and gadgets have their uses thanks to great level design. Stealth games can be compared to puzzles, and each room in DE:HR has multiple solutions to it. You can crawl through vents around your enemies, hack into the security system and turn turrets or robots against them, move huge crates that offer you a shortcut or jump up high to snipe them. You also have some cool tactical augmentations that make things easier and allow you to better plan or execute your actions. You can see through walls, turn invisible or run silently without alerting enemies. It’s all very fun, and part of the reason for my inflated play time – other than just enjoying the stroll slowly and taking in all the details of this beautifully crafted world (or, uh, alt-tabbing) – is because I always wanted to explore each region to its fullest after I cleared it of enemies, in order to see all the alternate routes I didn’t utilize.

You can also just shoot your way through, but here is my main complaint about the game, and it’s a fairly big one. DE:HR, strangely, offers you a huge array of tools, from lethal to non-lethal, loud or silent, but doesn’t encourage their use. You can silently kill people with your crossbow, loudly blast them with a rocket launcher, tranquilize them, stun them, throw grenades, set mines, use robots, or just engage in massive gunfights with several fun options in weaponry. And while the fighting mechanics aren’t top of the end, from what I toyed around with, they’re still fun. On the hardest difficulty you die very quickly if you’re reckless, but your enemies aren’t bullet sponges, either – and that makes for intense battles. The problem with all of this is that DE:HR rewards an extremely specific game style. It’s not even that it’s just stealth – it’s stealth takedowns (melee). Meaning that even all your stealth equipment might go unused.

If you don’t care about min-maxing, this won’t matter to you. But I have this suspicion that most gamers do want to unlock more powers, and when you get 10 XP for shooting down an enemy from afar, or 50 for taking them down in a non-lethal manner from up close, I imagine you’ll be inclined to do the latter. That 50 piles up in the long run. You also get bonuses at the end of the mission, depending on whether or not you were spotted, and whether an alarm was raised. Together, these bonuses amount to a huge sum that you’ll never enjoy in an aggressive approach, since it doesn’t offer some alternate reward for different achievements. This also caused me to quick-load over and over, since letting things develop dynamically felt more like a punishment. By the end of the game, a non-lethal, melee takedown playstyle will end up rewarding the player significantly more, mechanically, but will also become very repetitive. It’s disappointing that the game offers so many fun instruments, but motivates you with its XP distribution to use one single function alone throughout the entire playthrough. There’s an NG+ option in the director’s cut, and I might do a second run sometime in the future with my developed build, so I can enjoy fighting my enemies guilt-free and without that fear of missing out. But for a single playthrough, it ends up feeling like wasted potential. The gameplay offers you many options but draws a thick, red circle around a very specific one with a big smiley above it.

It’s a major complaint from my perspective, but regardless, as a whole, the experience remains terrific. For anyone interested in a stealth-oriented game with a mature and interesting story and awesome setting, DE:HR is highly recommended. For those who want a sci-fi action game, you can find it here too, albeit discriminated against. You need to approach it with a mentality that doesn’t fret about receiving the bare minimum XP.

reviewText: I had pretty high expectations when this first came out, and minus one section of the game they were blown away. Deus Ex Human Revolution - Director’s Cut Review

Introduction:
Deus Ex HRDC is a first person shooter with RPG elements, set in the near future in a world where chaos and conspiracy are rife. The majority of the game is free roam and the choices you make during the game will effect the world around you. Based before the original Deus Ex you are placed in the role of Adam Jensen an ex-swat team member, who now finds him self in charge of security for one of the largest biotechnology firms in America.

Story:
The Deus games have always been driven on conspiracy theory’s, Human Revolution is no different. All through the game you will be questioning who to trust and who not to, friends may become enemiesand enemies friends. The story really does a great job of keeping you suspicious, your never sure if your a good guy or a bad one. Add to that some of the choices the game gives you with no clear moral option, you’ll find yourself constantly second guessing yourself.
But the story does feel rushed at times and some questions it rises never really feel answered, some moments feel unexplained. In fact if you turn the commentary on in extras they them selves will tell you they ran out of time to fully realize all they wanted to do. Its a shame as it really does show, But what’s there is good and achieves exactly what they were trying to.

Gameplay:
As of late I’ve been struggling to get in to FPS games as the market is so saturated, but Deus Ex HRDC does truly offer something different from the norm. The controls are a pretty standard fair with one or two odd key placements, but nothing that hampers the experience. But its the augmentations that really put this game apart, some being basic things like faster sprinting or improving hacking skills. But its the stealth augments and things like punching through walls that really make this fun, and stealth is a big element of Deus. Its possible if your careful and cleaver to get through almost every mission without firing a shot, but at times you will probably have to so lucky even your weapons are upgradeable too.
If I have one major criticism of the gameplay, its the cover system. When you take cover or use a take down move you move into 3rd person view, this is great for a visual effect but feels really jarring in practice. It just doesn’t flow right and left me feeling like they should have ether made the whole game in 3rd person or found a way to do it in 1st person. Even the option like Skyrim where you can use ether view I would have welcomed over the way its executed here, I also feel that FPS vets will probably not use the cover system anyway.

Presentation:
The graphics are great for a 2 year old game and really do give that futuristic atmosphere. Some maps do feel like your walking down the same corridor fifteen times as there all so similar, but this is to be expected. Thankfully most levels are in more open settings with a wider verity of surroundings. There at times is a almost Blade Runner feel to the game, this is really emphasized by the neon lit menus and displays in the game. The character models are great too, with every character seeming unique and fresh.

Conclusion:
I really enjoyed Deus, more than I thought I would. If your looking for something a little deeper than the standard FPS then really look no farther. With a deep plot that to me seem heavily inspired by the works of Isaac Asimov and gameplay that’s a little different I found it a real breath of fresh air. There’s really not a lot here not to like and I would recommend it highly to anyone into FPS games.

See this and other reviews here http://www.cyberusuk.com/post/114658327513/deus-ex-human-revolution-directors-cut-review

Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a surprisingly good game.

I'd been told it was a good game previously, but never had a chance to try it out. By the time I remembered about the game, it was a few years after release and the graphics looked somewhat dated and I was foolish enough to give the game a skip based on that.

Then a friend of mine offered me a spare copy of the game going free, so I thought 'Ack, why the heck not!' and installed with haste. I played it straight over the following three days, putting 25.8 hours into the game, completing it on the hardest difficulty (or at least, the hardest available. I think there might be an even harder level now available after completing the game).

Oh boy, it was good.

Problem was, I went through the entire game without killing anyone. Or so I thought. Then I remembered I shot someone in the tutorial. Whoops. Oh well, just an achievement.

The game was rather easy to play, especially if you play non-lethal ghost. I've not tried out going loud - I suspect it'd be much harder, considering the amount of damage they deal on harder difficulties. So one might want to take that into mind.

Gameplay wise the game is above average - it's not exactly a great shooter, but the stealth is decent enough. It could be improved and I hope in the new game they make the combat a little more intuitive and/or realistic. But there will always be more one can want.

Yet what makes it great is the world and the story, and how people react to your actions. It feels nice when people comment about your lack of lethal use throughout the game - and, without spoiling anything, saving certain characters also happens to have a significant impact on the game too.

Obviously in my review, however basic it may be, I'm biased to a degree because I didn't actually purchase the game - but having played it, I would've bought it (at sale price, because I'm stingy) had I know what the game was actually like to player.


P.S. Illuminati
P.S.S. Thanks Zero!

Even though I already own DXHR and the DLC, I bought this because they fixed a number of things.  First they combined the DLC into the game which makes sense as the DLC shows what happens to you after you leave Hengsha in the stasis tube.  Then (and this is the big one) they fixed the three boss fights.  If you set up Jensen as a brawler and killing isn't an issue, then these fights weren't a big deal.  But if you prefer an emphasis on stealth and electronic surveillance and prefer a more pacifistic approach, then you may have had some issues.\n\nSince I already had the game and the DLC, I only paid $5 which is about $5 more than I should have paid for a bugfix.

Worth every single penny that I placed. Side quest and hidden paths are not only interesting and offer different ways to tackle an objective, but also adds to the overall plot and lets you feel more immersed in the universe.\n\n

Deus Ex HR is personally one of my favourite games of all time, top 10 at least. Like the original Deus Ex, it's very open world before open world games became all the rage. Although the game is still driven by quests, you are given alot of latitude in how you do them. You can be mega sneaky, or run and gun, or whatever.
I thought that the story was particuarly well done. You are Adam Jenson, an ex-cop who was brought back to life with cybernetics (ever seen this plot before? =) and now works for the people who designed the augmentations that saved him.
As with many games of this genre, your past comes back to haunt you and everything is not what it seems, etc.
The story is very long, it took me about 38 hours on easy mode (almost certainly take longer on hard mode). however, I personally loved playing it.
I've always been a big fan of the cyberpunk genre and Deus Ex HR delivers in spades, with tons of augmentations you can get (some of them rather useless imho, but I suppose it all depends on your playstyle.)
The plot is long and involved and eventually winds up with you having to decide the future of humanity (something else common in games I have noticed.. =)
I personally thought the graphics, and especially the cutscenes were great, if you have a powerful enough computer, playing it in full 1080 is beautiful.
I really can't reccommend this game highly enough, especially now that they have incorperated the DLC. My only niggle was with the inventory, which is kind of limited, but then I suppose that is sort of realistic.
There are lots of weapons in the game, some great, some useless without augs, but as I said above, because it's an open world game, you get the benefit of choice.
The characters are well written and the voice acting is really good, although you may find that the fact that Jenson has only one kind of voice (deep and husky, sort of menacing, like some action movie stars.. =) gets a bit samey after a while.
Still the only things I can fault in this game are very small things that are really just a matter of personal taste.
Overall, if you like cyberpunk and you like FPS and stealth, then grab this game.

reviewText:
I'm writing this review from the perspective of someone who's never touched the first game.

Deus Ex: Human Revolution, to me, is the pinnacle of modern RPG games. It has super satisfying gunplay and extremely tense stealth moments when playing on the hardest difficulty. The areas are incredibly detailed and you are rewarded greatly for not barging though every room. Around every corner there's some kind of secret, a piece of lore in the form of an eBook, Email, Newspaper, etc., and there's always multiple ways to attack any given situation (With some exception to scripted boss fights, which still can technically be taken down any way you please, I took out the first boss with sniper headshots instead of using the explosives in the room)

The hub areas are massive and filled with unique stories and side quests to be done. The world is alive with police, gang members, and civilians, all able to share specifically two pieces of dialogue with you.

The combat in this game is extremely satisfying, as is the stealth, as are the persuasion moments, as are the non-lethal takedowns, as are the lethal takedowns. This game lets you approach in any way you choose and you can have a good time doing it.

That's being said, this game obviously is not without it's faults, and here's a quick pro/con list to help sort some of these things out.


PROS:

Stealth and Combat are equally satisfying:  Though one option is technically better, and I'll get to that in a moment, neither is more satisfying than the other. The stealth mechanics work really well, where if one enemy thinks he sees you the others aren't immediatly alerted. They'll question whether the guy who saw you is going crazy or drunk or something before searching for you, if they even do. Enemies don't just instantly drop what they're doing, they go through a few stages of detection. Oblivious, Suspicious, Alterted, and Hostile. At each stage it will take longer for them to ignore you, and they will be more and more alert. The gunplay is also extremely well put together, with the guns feeling satisfying and being extremely fun to use effectively. So in the event you're caught, you won't feel dissatisfied (Other than with your lack of ability to stay hidden)


The areas are extremely detailed: There's something unique around every corner, and if you pay close enough attention you can find terminals to hack that lead to weapon mods, money, and ammo. This game rewards you for not rushing it, it rewards you for thinking, and it rewards exploration in a really nice way.

These are really the two main pros, obviously there's the interesting story backed with gamey voice acting that we're all used to. Some of the voice acting is pretty good, but most of it is pretty corny and obviously read from a script, but that's okay. Now onto the con.

Con:

Stealth is clearly the superior way to play. Non-lethal takedowns and hacking reward extremely highly. Normal kills get you 10 whatever points, headshots get you 20, while non-lethal takedowns always get you 30 or more. Hacking also gives you points, so even if you know the code to a door or computer, you might as well just hack it for the extra points and upgrades. Using stealth you can easily unlock every augment in the game, which breaks a lot of replay value. The only reason not to use stealth would be to see how the story changes when you kill everyone, which is extremely difficult on the hardest setting. I wish that it wasn't such a clear choice to go for stealth if you're looking for all the money and upgrades, but it is.

Anyways, this game is extremely fun, and very deep. There's tons of content and i've barely scratched the surface of the game 12 hours into it, because I can't stop finding new places to go and new areas to explore. This game does exploration and discovery in a uniquely satsisfying way and I highly recommend picking it up.
A thought provocing tale that pulls on your heart and minds, dividing you much like the world in Deus Ex: Human Revolution. Will you seek the truth? Or will you cover it up?

DE:HR is a fantastic experience with enjoyable writing and acting, mature themes and some of the coolest art direction I’ve seen. My main disappointment is how it motivates you to play in a very narrow way (a certain stealth approach); rendering all of the cool gadgets you collect null. I’ll explain later.

The game throws you right into the middle of things, and you need to pay attention to understand who’s who and what’s what. There’s no slow prologue telling how the world came to be in the state it is and how you find yourself there. It's something I like, because it helps establish this sense of realism that sticks throughout the entire game - that this is an actual world, not dependent on your existence to continue moving. You are part of it, not the center of it. Still, I’ll help you with the basic orientation.

You’re Adam Jensen, former SWAT and currently chief of security at a biotech company, that is at the forefront of human augmentation (mechanical upgrades to humans) research and development. You are an existing and set character, not a blank slate, so the choices you make are limited to what is reasonable for Adam to do. Many people enjoy creating their characters out of scratch. This is not that kind of game. Personally, I prefer this format. It’s a fine balance that offers some amount of input, but not too much to the point that it sacrifices the depth of the story just to give you more choices that end up being shallow. Speaking of which, the consequences of your decisions are also pleasantly felt later on. I didn't find them to be too drastic, but the small nods were satisfying nevertheless.

Augmentation is the main topic the world is embroiled in at 2027, and the debate about its pros and cons extends to ethical, political, economical and social aspects. It’s a nice take on sci-fi that manages to keep things still relatively grounded and credible, while also enjoying some creative liberties where the developers wanted to emphasize the subject. Suspension of disbelief is required in some places more than others, but overall the game manages to sell a believable, alternate world. And it’s a bleak one. Earth is in the midst of a cyber renaissance, but once you move away from the socialites to the streets and alleyways, you will feel an atmosphere that is opposite from the optimistic aura of revolution that is present among the upper class. The change the world is going through isn’t embraced by all, doesn’t grace all, and there is an obvious tension in the air. The title of the next game is Mankind Divided, but the hints and seeds of that segregation are already found here.

The progression through levels is linear. While you revisit some of them, they’re in a changed state, and you can never go back to a level you’ve finished. They’re divided into the regular hub areas you know from most RPGs – open areas for your exploration to restock, talk with people, do side quests, etc – and the hostile levels that are much more fight or stealth oriented. Less talk, more action.

Augmentations are the source of your abilities, and they’re varied enough to make leveling up an exciting occurrence. DE:HR isn't plagued by endless passive upgrades (e.g. 4% damage increase) that leave you with nothing to look forward to. You have plenty of enhancements that are new abilities, which allow you to do things you couldn’t previously achieve. There’s an interesting dialogue system that triggers with certain, important NPCs. One augmentation helps you better analyze these key figures to find the correct answer. Hacking is everywhere, and the mini-game that seems confusing at first turns out to be simple and fun. You can choose to jump higher to reach new areas, punch through weak walls or move heavy objects to open additional routes. And on the RPG note, you even have an old-school inventory system that forces you to choose what to take and what to ditch. Weapons or stealth equipment? You can't have everything.

All these abilities and gadgets have their uses thanks to great level design. Stealth games can be compared to puzzles, and each room in DE:HR has multiple solutions to it. You can crawl through vents around your enemies, hack into the security system and turn turrets or robots against them, move huge crates that offer you a shortcut or jump up high to snipe them. You also have some cool tactical augmentations that make things easier and allow you to better plan or execute your actions. You can see through walls, turn invisible or run silently without alerting enemies. It’s all very fun, and part of the reason for my inflated play time – other than just enjoying the stroll slowly and taking in all the details of this beautifully crafted world (or, uh, alt-tabbing) – is because I always wanted to explore each region to its fullest after I cleared it of enemies, in order to see all the alternate routes I didn’t utilize.

You can also just shoot your way through, but here is my main complaint about the game, and it’s a fairly big one. DE:HR, strangely, offers you a huge array of tools, from lethal to non-lethal, loud or silent, but doesn’t encourage their use. You can silently kill people with your crossbow, loudly blast them with a rocket launcher, tranquilize them, stun them, throw grenades, set mines, use robots, or just engage in massive gunfights with several fun options in weaponry. And while the fighting mechanics aren’t top of the end, from what I toyed around with, they’re still fun. On the hardest difficulty you die very quickly if you’re reckless, but your enemies aren’t bullet sponges, either – and that makes for intense battles. The problem with all of this is that DE:HR rewards an extremely specific game style. It’s not even that it’s just stealth – it’s stealth takedowns (melee). Meaning that even all your stealth equipment might go unused.

If you don’t care about min-maxing, this won’t matter to you. But I have this suspicion that most gamers do want to unlock more powers, and when you get 10 XP for shooting down an enemy from afar, or 50 for taking them down in a non-lethal manner from up close, I imagine you’ll be inclined to do the latter. That 50 piles up in the long run. You also get bonuses at the end of the mission, depending on whether or not you were spotted, and whether an alarm was raised. Together, these bonuses amount to a huge sum that you’ll never enjoy in an aggressive approach, since it doesn’t offer some alternate reward for different achievements. This also caused me to quick-load over and over, since letting things develop dynamically felt more like a punishment. By the end of the game, a non-lethal, melee takedown playstyle will end up rewarding the player significantly more, mechanically, but will also become very repetitive. It’s disappointing that the game offers so many fun instruments, but motivates you with its XP distribution to use one single function alone throughout the entire playthrough. There’s an NG+ option in the director’s cut, and I might do a second run sometime in the future with my developed build, so I can enjoy fighting my enemies guilt-free and without that fear of missing out. But for a single playthrough, it ends up feeling like wasted potential. The gameplay offers you many options but draws a thick, red circle around a very specific one with a big smiley above it.

It’s a major complaint from my perspective, but regardless, as a whole, the experience remains terrific. For anyone interested in a stealth-oriented game with a mature and interesting story and awesome setting, DE:HR is highly recommended. For those who want a sci-fi action game, you can find it here too, albeit discriminated against. You need to approach it with a mentality that doesn’t fret about receiving the bare minimum XP.

I played this game right after completing Dark Souls 2, and all I wanted was to play a FPS title. When I first started the game, I felt that the controls and interface was rather clunky. While the controls can be remapped in the menu, you would have to slowly get used to the interface, such as how to hack, how to upgrade your gear when you level up, and cleaning your inventory.

The story mainly revolves around the ethics of augmentations, that being when technology advances and when people have the ability to modify their own body (even their mind) such that they function better. This extends beyond mere prostheses for the disabled such as protagonist Adam Jensen, but also willing modifications on perfectly fine bodies. While the benefits are apparant, those who oppose come forward with arguments such as the misuse in crimes or the alteration of oneself away from the image of God.

What really attracts me is how the game is open to multiple gameplay approaches. As mentioned, I started the game wanting an FPS, so I went in guns-blazing killing everything I see. Halfway through, I started to incorporate stealth after upgrading specific augmentations and in the end, the game offered me an ending that defined my time as Adam Jensen. There are a total of 12 unique endings and in the one I got, Adam says and I quote: Technologies are invented to make our lives easier -- not our choices. The problem comes when we forget that.

9/10

Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a prequel to the original Deus Ex game and follows the story of Adam Jensen, a security chief at an augmentation (cybernetic implantation) industry, who finds himself augmented against his will and put against a myterious conspiracy he must discover and twwart in time
The story of Human Revolution keeps itself interesting for the whole game, with a very clever portrait of technology advancements debates, few cameos from characters of Deus Ex and a good bunch of original protagonists. As with every Deus Ex title there is a lot of reading and exploring to do for players who really want to dig further in the game's setting: doing so even awards you nice chunks of experience every time
Gameplay-wise, one must say that Human Revolution offers less freedom of action than its predecessor. While in the original Deus Ex you could go around destroying anyone and anything or decide to either incapacitate or plain evade both regular enemies without any consequence, truly allowing you to slowly build your own way to overcome the game's challenges, this sequel still gives you the same amount of freedom, but turns the table more in favor of an action-packed approach. Each boss encounter requires you to kill your enemy and every one of them are very durable augmented agents that will torn apart a player that relayed only on stealth and evasion up to that point. You can't run away either. There are also several instances in the game where going full killing mode against your enemies is required to achieve certain results
The Director's Cut DLC tried to fix such design choices by adding to the bosses arenas more way to eliminate them with indirect means. However, it's worth mentioning that you still HAVE to kill them and they have been severly buffed up from the first version of the game, to the point that even trying to off them with hacking or unconventional means is very hard without some protective or straight combat augs
The Missing Link DLC is a four hours worthy new content that was fully integrated in the main story of Human Revolution with the Director's Cut. The DLC takes place on a Belltower cargo ship, the Hei Zhen Zhu, and requires you to find and neutralize the local mercenary leader in order to continue your main story to Singapore. Whyle the ship features very crampy environments, the whole DLC still feels like a Deus Ex game, with plenty of alternative options to choose from. The final boss of the Missing Link is also much more Deus-Ex-esque than the ones from the vanilla game
I would totally reccomend Deus Ex: Human Revolution due to its outsanding story and gameplay united with a huge replay value that allows you to experience a different kind of game every time you decide how to deal with the enemies and the other NPCS your own special way differently
Hate the boss battles but every else about this game with exception to the story and some of the voice acting is brilliant\njust LESS Yellow, Brown and Black and BRING SOME COLOUR IN TO THE GAME!
I can't wait for the movie.

reviewText: At first I thought it would be another Square Enix failed attempt in making an old style game come back to life, but then after playing it for awhile it became not fully repetitive (unless you have to do take downs 50 times, hacking 50 times or knock outs 100 times...).  I give this game a 4.2 out of 5 because like I said some repetitiveness in certain things, but also the random frame drops that could occur which could glitch out the whole game making you fall out of the universe in some fashion like Assassin Creed Unity. Other then that the story has its ups and down, but the action of stealth can keep you on your toes trying to keep you running or else you could die from a stray turret round.

Sneak up on anybody and kill them. check.\n'nuff said. 9/10.

Deus Ex Human Revolution - Director’s Cut Review

Introduction:
Deus Ex HRDC is a first person shooter with RPG elements, set in the near future in a world where chaos and conspiracy are rife. The majority of the game is free roam and the choices you make during the game will effect the world around you. Based before the original Deus Ex you are placed in the role of Adam Jensen an ex-swat team member, who now finds him self in charge of security for one of the largest biotechnology firms in America.

Story:
The Deus games have always been driven on conspiracy theory’s, Human Revolution is no different. All through the game you will be questioning who to trust and who not to, friends may become enemiesand enemies friends. The story really does a great job of keeping you suspicious, your never sure if your a good guy or a bad one. Add to that some of the choices the game gives you with no clear moral option, you’ll find yourself constantly second guessing yourself.
But the story does feel rushed at times and some questions it rises never really feel answered, some moments feel unexplained. In fact if you turn the commentary on in extras they them selves will tell you they ran out of time to fully realize all they wanted to do. Its a shame as it really does show, But what’s there is good and achieves exactly what they were trying to.

Gameplay:
As of late I’ve been struggling to get in to FPS games as the market is so saturated, but Deus Ex HRDC does truly offer something different from the norm. The controls are a pretty standard fair with one or two odd key placements, but nothing that hampers the experience. But its the augmentations that really put this game apart, some being basic things like faster sprinting or improving hacking skills. But its the stealth augments and things like punching through walls that really make this fun, and stealth is a big element of Deus. Its possible if your careful and cleaver to get through almost every mission without firing a shot, but at times you will probably have to so lucky even your weapons are upgradeable too.
If I have one major criticism of the gameplay, its the cover system. When you take cover or use a take down move you move into 3rd person view, this is great for a visual effect but feels really jarring in practice. It just doesn’t flow right and left me feeling like they should have ether made the whole game in 3rd person or found a way to do it in 1st person. Even the option like Skyrim where you can use ether view I would have welcomed over the way its executed here, I also feel that FPS vets will probably not use the cover system anyway.

Presentation:
The graphics are great for a 2 year old game and really do give that futuristic atmosphere. Some maps do feel like your walking down the same corridor fifteen times as there all so similar, but this is to be expected. Thankfully most levels are in more open settings with a wider verity of surroundings. There at times is a almost Blade Runner feel to the game, this is really emphasized by the neon lit menus and displays in the game. The character models are great too, with every character seeming unique and fresh.

Conclusion:
I really enjoyed Deus, more than I thought I would. If your looking for something a little deeper than the standard FPS then really look no farther. With a deep plot that to me seem heavily inspired by the works of Isaac Asimov and gameplay that’s a little different I found it a real breath of fresh air. There’s really not a lot here not to like and I would recommend it highly to anyone into FPS games.

See this and other reviews here http://www.cyberusuk.com/post/114658327513/deus-ex-human-revolution-directors-cut-review

I have never been so immersed into a video game before, and enjoyed every minute of playing Deus Ex.
Deux Ex has the coolest and most interesting universe and plots of any game I have played, portraying a very believable and frightening future of a world in moral conflict and on the brink of civil war.
The combat revolves around the player taking either a stealth approach or an aggresive one. Either way being fun, leaving players wanting to redo a checkpoint to perfect a certain method to complete it.
This kind of gameplay has innevitably resulted in AI being a bit stuipid and too oblivious at times. Additionally, some boss fights are bit over the top and unnesccary.
However, the variety of skills the player has to choose from and the unique environments of each chapter/level overshadows these faults.
Deus Ex has been an example and of why games should be taken more seriously, and have alot more potential than being viewed as violent shoot em ups' as seen in the past.

reviewText:
This may very well be one of the longest reviews I will ever write...

First off, I'll admit it. When I first played Deus Ex: Human Revolution, I didn't like it at all. I found the game to be boring and difficult. It may also have something to do with the fact that I first played this on the Playstation 3, but I digress. The fact is, this game is probably unlike any other game I've ever played in my life.

You play as Adam Jensen, an ex-cop now working for Sarif Industries, a massive company that is pretty much the poster-boy for cyberpunk mega-conglomerates. When the company is about to move to a new location, it gets hit by a terrorist attack, leaving Jensen near-death while he watches his lover, Megan Reed, get killed. In typical Robocop fashion, he is rebuilt using  AUGMENTATIONS™  . Six months later, he is back at the company, and is now on a quest to discover the truth of what really happened that fateful night.

As far as presentation goes, I've heard a lot of people give this game a hard time for having a consistently yellow/orange aesthetic to it. Personally, I didn't mind this that much, and thought the game looked fine. Actually, I'd say that in a lot of areas, the game looks fantastic, especially on some of the later levels. (I personally thought that the penthouse level was absolutely gorgeous) There's so many fine details in every nook and cranny in this game, that it really makes the game look and feel like it's own universe. Of course, looking at the Final Fantasy games, this is to be expected from Square Enix. If I really have any complaints, I thought that the characters sometimes felt a bit robotic, and the lip-syncing can kinda get screwy at times. However, this is a pretty small problem that can be overlooked.

I say that because, for the most part, the voice actors really do a good job; putting a lot of effort forth for some pretty riveting dialogue at times. I personally thought that the voice actor of Jensen, Elias Toufexis, did an amazing job potraying his role. As a matter of fact, the sound design in most of the game is actually really good; the guns sound like they have a punch to them, and of course, a bunch of little details here and there that, again, make this game truly come to life.

Now, when it comes to the music, it ranges from pretty good" to "♥♥♥♥ing incredible". Some of the tracks on here are an audible feast. I just hope that Mankind Divided has just as good of a soundtrack

reviewText: This is one of the best games I have ever played. It combines the best stealth mechanics of the metal gear solid games, the cover based shooting of any modern 3rd person shooter, and one of the best narratives since Bioshock. The mechanics are similar to the system shock series, with spending points to upgrade your augmentations and the same inventory system. The shooting and stealth provide enough of a challenge to make you not feel like a tank, and the behind-the-scenes stuff and extra missions are exemplary. Every decision you make influences the world around you, whether it be through rewards, subtly different endings, or dialogue. It makes you feel like you are a part of the world, and I would give this game a 9 out of 10 stars.

reviewText:
After owning it on the 360, and now on the PC, I have to say that this is a really good game. It's not only a decent game, but it is a great Deus Ex game. Especially considering the failure that was The Fall, and the controversial Invisible War, DEHR is a fantastic installment to the series.

The graphics, the gameplay mechanics, the inventory, item construction and customization, the character upgrades, all of these are solid. Then we get into the story and dialogue. They are like nothing I have experienced before. Once you get the dialogue Praxis upgrade, it opens up a whole new gameplay feature, one that allows you to not only witness the effects of your choices during the dialogue sequence (not just after), but gives you a whole new way to play the game. It allows you to actually strategize during a conversation based on the individual person you're talking to and their personality, along with their emotional state at any given time, not just click one phrase and hope that the NPC has a favorable response to that particular selection.

I am one of the few who actually like DE: Invisible War, but I have to admit that the inventory and (oh god) the dialogue and voice acting were bland and boring at best. Human Revolution doesn't fall victim to any of the failures of its older brother (and some would say a VERY distant relative). The voice acting is superb, the inventory is akin to The Conspiracy, item upgrades are more like the original, and the story and missions give you that sense of urgency that the original had.

It's not just a good shooter, but it is a fantastic RPG. I've got to say that this is one (pre)sequel that I am proud to own and experience. Definitely recommended. A solid 9/10

I didn't ask for this...Deus Ex: Human Revolution is what you'd call a modern classic. It's one of the greatest games of our time, and will most likely stand the test of time. I've bought and played through it twice to completion, once on PS3 and now on PC, and the Director's Cut includes the fun and story-adding Missing Link DLC. This game is a worthy addition to any gamer's library, and now I think it's time to explain why.

Gameplay
Surveying the warehouse floor, you see five guards patrolling. You could snatch the shotgun that lies, unattended, in the office, or you could hack the security system that will turn the turret systems against the guards. You could cloak and move silently past them. You could choke or stab each one, dragging them away from sight and picking them off one by one. You could unlock the doors, sneak through the vent, throw a concussion grenade, drop a box on their head... the possibilities are essentially endless. You want to try an approach in this game, go ahead. Sure, the pure combat approach may not be the most fun shooter you've ever played, but the stealth system in this game is great, and the free-form missions enable you to play multiple saves and never have the same experience twice.
You can augment your character with a large variety of different augmentations, which all have practical use in many instances throughout the game. There isn't really one that you will regret buying, though, still, spend wisely! The only thing that lets this section down are still the iffy boss fights. There still isn't a true stealth option, at least not to my knowledge.

Story
You play Adam Jensen, security chief of one of America's largest biotech industries. One day, before going to present a new technology to the world, your offices are attacked, and you left for dead. Resurrected by the very biotechnology you protected, Adam now investigates the biggest conspiracy of the 2020s in an effort to bring justice to the people who murdered his friends and coworkers. It's a very good story and excellent mystery. Well worth playing just for the story.

Graphics, Atmosphere, and Sound
The graphics are, perhaps, slightly dated, but still look crisp enough that you'll enjoy it.
The atmosphere of the game is spot on. Deus Ex paints a future that is worrying, but you'll still think that Adam Jensen looks damned awesome in those augmented shades. The gritty, cyberpunk world is well worth exploring every nook and cranny for.
The sound of the game is also spot on. The rattle of the combat rifle, the hiss as you reload the magazine, the subtle footsteps, the idle chatter of the enemies, and who can forget the incredible theme song, Icarus. Another great element to a great game.

Conclusion
An rollicking mystery with intriguing plot twists and interesting characters who you can't trust 100%, this game is most definitely worth playing twice, even more than twice... This game isn't perfect, but after all, it was only made by humans...
A+

This may very well be one of the longest reviews I will ever write...

First off, I'll admit it. When I first played Deus Ex: Human Revolution, I didn't like it at all. I found the game to be boring and difficult. It may also have something to do with the fact that I first played this on the Playstation 3, but I digress. The fact is, this game is probably unlike any other game I've ever played in my life.

You play as Adam Jensen, an ex-cop now working for Sarif Industries, a massive company that is pretty much the poster-boy for cyberpunk mega-conglomerates. When the company is about to move to a new location, it gets hit by a terrorist attack, leaving Jensen near-death while he watches his lover, Megan Reed, get killed. In typical Robocop fashion, he is rebuilt using  AUGMENTATIONS™  . Six months later, he is back at the company, and is now on a quest to discover the truth of what really happened that fateful night.

As far as presentation goes, I've heard a lot of people give this game a hard time for having a consistently yellow/orange aesthetic to it. Personally, I didn't mind this that much, and thought the game looked fine. Actually, I'd say that in a lot of areas, the game looks fantastic, especially on some of the later levels. (I personally thought that the penthouse level was absolutely gorgeous) There's so many fine details in every nook and cranny in this game, that it really makes the game look and feel like it's own universe. Of course, looking at the Final Fantasy games, this is to be expected from Square Enix. If I really have any complaints, I thought that the characters sometimes felt a bit robotic, and the lip-syncing can kinda get screwy at times. However, this is a pretty small problem that can be overlooked.

I say that because, for the most part, the voice actors really do a good job; putting a lot of effort forth for some pretty riveting dialogue at times. I personally thought that the voice actor of Jensen, Elias Toufexis, did an amazing job potraying his role. As a matter of fact, the sound design in most of the game is actually really good; the guns sound like they have a punch to them, and of course, a bunch of little details here and there that, again, make this game truly come to life.

Now, when it comes to the music, it ranges from pretty good" to "♥♥♥♥ing incredible". Some of the tracks on here are an audible feast. I just hope that Mankind Divided has just as good of a soundtrack

reviewText: This is one of the best games I have ever played. It combines the best stealth mechanics of the metal gear solid games, the cover based shooting of any modern 3rd person shooter, and one of the best narratives since Bioshock. The mechanics are similar to the system shock series, with spending points to upgrade your augmentations and the same inventory system. The shooting and stealth provide enough of a challenge to make you not feel like a tank, and the behind-the-scenes stuff and extra missions are exemplary. Every decision you make influences the world around you, whether it be through rewards, subtly different endings, or dialogue. It makes you feel like you are a part of the world, and I would give this game a 9 out of 10 stars.

Having played both the original Deus Ex: HR and Deus Ex: The Missing Link, the Director's cut brings the game to another level. The boss fights and other glitches have been fixed, making it much more enjoyable to play with. The gameplay is good and it is definitely recommended

Deus Ex Human Revolution - Director’s Cut Review

Introduction:
Deus Ex HRDC is a first person shooter with RPG elements, set in the near future in a world where chaos and conspiracy are rife. The majority of the game is free roam and the choices you make during the game will effect the world around you. Based before the original Deus Ex you are placed in the role of Adam Jensen an ex-swat team member, who now finds him self in charge of security for one of the largest biotechnology firms in America.

Story:
The Deus games have always been driven on conspiracy theory’s, Human Revolution is no different. All through the game you will be questioning who to trust and who not to, friends may become enemiesand enemies friends. The story really does a great job of keeping you suspicious, your never sure if your a good guy or a bad one. Add to that some of the choices the game gives you with no clear moral option, you’ll find yourself constantly second guessing yourself.
But the story does feel rushed at times and some questions it rises never really feel answered, some moments feel unexplained. In fact if you turn the commentary on in extras they them selves will tell you they ran out of time to fully realize all they wanted to do. Its a shame as it really does show, But what’s there is good and achieves exactly what they were trying to.

Gameplay:
As of late I’ve been struggling to get in to FPS games as the market is so saturated, but Deus Ex HRDC does truly offer something different from the norm. The controls are a pretty standard fair with one or two odd key placements, but nothing that hampers the experience. But its the augmentations that really put this game apart, some being basic things like faster sprinting or improving hacking skills. But its the stealth augments and things like punching through walls that really make this fun, and stealth is a big element of Deus. Its possible if your careful and cleaver to get through almost every mission without firing a shot, but at times you will probably have to so lucky even your weapons are upgradeable too.
If I have one major criticism of the gameplay, its the cover system. When you take cover or use a take down move you move into 3rd person view, this is great for a visual effect but feels really jarring in practice. It just doesn’t flow right and left me feeling like they should have ether made the whole game in 3rd person or found a way to do it in 1st person. Even the option like Skyrim where you can use ether view I would have welcomed over the way its executed here, I also feel that FPS vets will probably not use the cover system anyway.

Presentation:
The graphics are great for a 2 year old game and really do give that futuristic atmosphere. Some maps do feel like your walking down the same corridor fifteen times as there all so similar, but this is to be expected. Thankfully most levels are in more open settings with a wider verity of surroundings. There at times is a almost Blade Runner feel to the game, this is really emphasized by the neon lit menus and displays in the game. The character models are great too, with every character seeming unique and fresh.

Conclusion:
I really enjoyed Deus, more than I thought I would. If your looking for something a little deeper than the standard FPS then really look no farther. With a deep plot that to me seem heavily inspired by the works of Isaac Asimov and gameplay that’s a little different I found it a real breath of fresh air. There’s really not a lot here not to like and I would recommend it highly to anyone into FPS games.

See this and other reviews here http://www.cyberusuk.com/post/114658327513/deus-ex-human-revolution-directors-cut-review

Beautiful soundtrack, stunning visuals and intriguing story. I recently bought this game in a sale and this game has quickly become one of my all time best singleplayer games. I r8 8/8, this game is a must buy!

Human Revolution is a worthy successor to the Deux Ex franchise and an interesting game on its own. It stays true to the design philosophies of earlier installments, allowing the player to choose multiple paths to navigate the fairly sizable maps. While there are truly memorable moments (the excellent Hengsha hub), the script is inconsistent with a subpar third act.

The visuals have aged gracefully for the most part, but the playing areas do feel too confined (old hardware limitations, in all likelihood). Map design ranges from inspired (such as the Detroit area and the Tai Yong Medical tower) to very commonplace with bland industrial facilities.

The gameplay, however, is great fun. While not groundbreaking, the cover shooting is as enjoyable as the stealth approach. The hacking minigame could become potentially annoying to some. The augmentations could have been a little more creative, as you'll probably grab all the interesting ones by midgame. The boss fights, as has been extensively covered, are a pain in the ♥♥♥, even in the Director's Cut.

An exceptional game, but not as revolutionary as the original Deus Ex.

I went into this game thinking it would be your every day shooter game with average story and decent game mechanics. What I got was something much more pleasing. Deus Ex: Human Revolution has got to be one of my most favorite games of all time. Every penny I spent on this game was well worth it and I will never forget the experience Human Revolution has given me.

The game takes place in the future where robotic limbs and augmentation is possible. A lot of thought went into this concept as you've got the pro-life supporters stating that augmentation is wrong and that you shouldn't do anything to your body. On the other hand you've got those who support human augmentation stating that this is how the human race will evolve. You play as Adam Jensen- a security guard. You used to be fully human" without any augmentations until a day came where you were attacked by an augmented human and left nearly for dead. Practically every limb in Jensen's body has been replaced due to the severity of the attack he barely lived through.

6 months fly by and you are called in again to help stop those responsible for the attack on Serif Industries and get revenge on those that made you what you are. The story is rich and deep- and the characters are very memorable. Adam questions if he is still human
date: or something more. As mentioned- the developers put a lot of thought into the story of this game and it stands out. I haven't played the game in months and I still remember the story as if I played the game yesterday.\n\nThe game mechanics are wonderful. It's more of stealth game or taking enemies out one by one than anything. Adam is not a Call of Duty soldier by any means and can't step into a middle of a room unprotected. The game requires strategy. You can tackle a level in several different way whether you try and go in fully stealthy or take out enemies every time they are encountered. You are rewarded in XP for exploring or not being seen at all or not killing enemies but rather
recommended: knocking them out. The more you level or find certain collectibles to upgrade your augments
hoursPlayed: the more you can do with them. For instance
voteText: you couldn't fall from a certain height without dying unless you got enough XP to purchase the Icarus upgrade which would allow you to fall from any height and not be hurt let alone die. Or you can't lift anything with the exception of like a remote unless you put XP into an upgrade that would allow you to move heavy things such as dumpsters. A great concept that makes the game challenging or sometimes making you wish you put your upgrade into some other augmentation based on the current situation you are in.\n\nThe game has branching paths. You can choose certain dialogue options and some of these options do have an impact on how the mission progresses or ends. You'll have speech checks that if you fail- could be the death of a hostage or information being withheld from you. Speaking certain things or asking questions helps you understand the story more. I've never been more interest in doing side quests and reading emails and everything as I have with Human Revolution. This game makes you want to complete the side quests. This game makes you want to explore and find out every little secret that you can find out about. And if that wasn't enough
helpfulPercent: the soundtrack to this game is beautiful and well compose and fits Human Revolution perfectly.\n\nDon't go into this game thinking you are a super soldier who can soak up bullets. You might be a very augmented individual- but you are still human and can take damage like crazy if you are careless. The best strategy of this game is to go in stealthy or taking enemies out one by one when necessary. Strategy is going to be your best friend in this game. If this is not your play style or you aren't willing to play that kind of play style
votesHelpful: don't get this game. However- if you are looking for a great story with lots of lore to get into along with great game mechanics
votesTotal: I cannot recommend this game enough."

A Surprise | Deus Ex
After getting this game, I didn't have much expectation. All I heard was that it was really good and was amazing. But that didn't seem like much to me at the moment. At first it was difficult. Rather than an average game this game offered  more  than it appeared to.

Gameplay & Detail

What's nice about Deus Ex, is that it gives you different approaches. In the beginning of the game they give you a weapon of your choice. Ones like either a quiet, ranged, and nonlethal rifle (Tranquilizer Rifle) or a quiet, close-ranged, nonlethal gun (Stun Gun). But if your the type to go out full gun, there's that too. Your given the option also to take an automatic rifle and etc. This really is the beginning of the amazing stuff about Deus Ex. Instead of forcing you into a play-style, it really just offers you many different ones. Not only that, but after the first few missions you arrive in Detroit. The city feels a bit abandoned (you feel like there would be more people) but slowly after learning the atmosphere of Deus Ex (and looking up at the sky, of course), you'd understand that the city that you walk in is some of the lowest parts of the city. It all ties in and makes a wonderful game with wonderful mechanics. In the very beginning, you also learn about a very important thing. Hacking. Hacking is used a  LOT  to manipulate your enviroment, such as opening doors, turning turrets onto your side or completely disabling them, or even just taking over giant robots roaming the level. What's cool though is that hacking is a mini puzzle game that are short and sometimes difficult (you have a limited time to beat the puzzle). All these mechanics and decisions Edios Montreal and Square Enix made really make the game hit a homerun (Take my word... IT'S REALLY GOOD). But there are downfalls right? Yeah there is. There's bugs. There's an anonymous X glitch. It occurs later in the game when you meet someone and then it glitches and dosen't allow you to talk to anyone in the game. But thankfully there's a way to  fix it.  I'm sure there's more bugs, but I haven't run into much except a few funny ones, like if you throw a box at someone it will insta-kill them usually (Like really tiny boxes). Otherwise the gameplay is fine and nothing bad happens usually.

Story
Ohhhhh.... this is the best of it. The Story. It takes an interesting topic about technology and messes with what's good about it. It's psychological and makes you think through everything. I won't spoil anything, but will just say this story alone is worth you buying. It makes you question about technology and just makes everything about technology seem corrupted at the same time feeling extremely useful. What's also cool is while you are going through the main story it allows you to make decisions that affect the game. You can choose to let  a terrorist  free  wth a hostage  or kill them. That affects everyone reacts towards you. It makes it interesting. As if it could not get any more interesting is that they made it where if you want to know and dive deep even more into the story is that you can go hack computers. So many things can be found in the computers. Computers have emails constantly on Deus Ex. They don't update, but you find emails that provide information on the story. Not just that but it provides sometimes codes for doors and etc. It makes it worth while hacking in.

Graphics
The graphics are reasonably good. While it's not  amazing , it's still pretty good. People look good and everything performs fine. I have an Alienware x51 i5 and I can perform it at usually a steady 60 frames per second. I do though have frame drops when on a mission sometimes, but not  bad drops  (it went done like 7 fps for a few seconds). Sometimes I've had a farther frame drop down to 30 at times when first entering the city. But it hasn't happened much since. Otherwise the graphics are fine and work well.

Overall
Deus Ex Human Revolution is amazing. It's worth every penny. Right now its $3.99, and I would throw your money at it now. It's a great singeplayer game with an amazing story with great mechanics. IT's definetely worth buying.

Rating":  Buy It. You can't go wrong."
